Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Galfredi Chauceri Poetae Angli Incipiunt Prologi in fabulas Canterburienses .
UWhan that april wᵗith his shourez swote
Þe drought of March haþ ꝑper/parcyd to þᵉ rote
And bathid eủer/rey veyn in such lycour
Of which vertu engendrid is the flour
Whan zepherus eke with his sweete breth
Enspired hath in euery holt and heth
The tendre croppes and the yong sonne
Hath in the Reyne his half cours y ronne
And smale foules makyn melody
That slepyn al the nyght with opyn ey
So prikkiþ hem nature in here coragez
Than longyn folk to gon on pilgrimagez
And palmers for to sekyn straunge strondez
To feere halwys sowt in sundry londys
And specially from eủer/rey shirez ende
Of Englond to Cauntyrbury thei wende
The holy blisful martyr for to seke
That hem hath holpyn when thei were seeke
Befell that in that seson on a day
In southwerk at the Tabbard I lay
Redy to wendyn on my pilgrimage
To Cauntyrbury with ful deuoute corage
At nyght were comyn to that hostelry
Welnygh nyne and twenty on a company
Of sundry folk by aventure y falle
In felawshipp ; and pilgrymes were þei alle
Thei toward Cauntyrbury wold ryde
The chaumbres and the stables were wyde
And wel we weryn easid at the best
And shortly whan the sonne was to rest
So hadde I spokyn with hem euerichon
That I was of thaire felavshipp a non
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure weye there as I yow deuyse
But neuyr the lesse whils I haue tyme ⁊and space
Er that I forthermore in this tale pace
Me thynketh yt accordaunt to Resoun
To telle yow al the condicyoun
Of ich of hem so as yt semyth me
And which thei were and of what degree
And eke in what aray that þei were in
And at a knyght wil I furst begyn
A knyght ther was and þᵗat a wurthi man
Þat fro þe tyme þat he furst began
To ryden out ; he louyd cheualry
Trouthe and honour fredam and courtasy
Full wurthi was he in his lordis warre
And therto had he rydyn no man so farre
Als wel in cristendome as in hethnesse
And euyr was honouryd for his wurthynesse
At Alisaundre was he whan yt was wonne
And oftyn tyme he had the boorde begonne
Abouyn al nacyon in pruce
In lectow hadde he presyng and ruce
No cristen man so ofte of his degree
In garnade at the sege eke had he be
Of algezer ; and ryden in belmary
At lyeys was he and at sataly
When thei were wonne and in grete see
At many a noble arme had he be
At mortal batailles had he been fiftene
And foughtyn for oure faith in tramysene
In listes thryes and ay slough his foo
This ilke wurthi knyght hadde ben also
Sum tyme with the lord of palaty
Agayn an othir hethyn in turky
And euyr more he hadde a soueraign pryce
And though he were wurthi he was wyse
And of his port als meke as is a mayde
He neuyr yit no vilany ne saide
In al his lyfe vnto no manyr wight
He was a verray perfyte gentil knyght
But for to telle yow of his aray
His hors weryn goode but yt he was not gay
Of fustion he werid a iuppon
Al be smorchid with his haberiou
For he was late come from his viage
And went to don his pilgrimage
Uith hym þer was his sone a yong sqwier
A louere and a lusty bachiler
With lokkes crulle and thei were leid in presse
Of twenty yeer of age he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of euyn lengthe
And wundyr delyuer and of gret strengthe
And hadde been sum tyme in cheualrye
In flaundres arteys and in picardye
And born hym wel as of so lytell space
In hope to stondyn in his ladyez grace
Enbrowded was he as yt were a mede
Al ful of fressh flourys white and rede
Syngyng he was or pipyng al the day
He was as fressh as is the moneth of may
Short was his gowne with slevys long ⁊and wyde
Wel couthe he sytte on hors and fayre ryde
He couth songez make and wel endyte
Iustyn ⁊and eke wel daunce purtray and wryte
So hote he louyd that by the nyghtirtale
He slept no more than doth the nyghtyngale
Curtays he was lowely and servysable
And carf before his fadir at the table
A yoman had he and seruauntz no mo
At that tyme for hym lyst ryde so
And he was clad in cote and hood of grene
A shef of pecok arwes bright and shene
Vndir his belt he bare ful thryftily
Wel couth he dresse his takil yomanly
His arwes droupid nought with fedirs lowe
And in his hand he bar a myghty bowe
A not hede had he with a brown visage
Of wodecraft wel couth he the vsage
Vppon his arme he bare a gay braser
And by his side a good swerd and a bokeler
And on that othir syde a gay dagger
Harneysid wel and sharp as poynt of sper
A cristofre on his breest of siluer shene
A horne he bar the bawdryke was of grene
A forster was he soothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a prioresse
That of her smylyng was boþᵉ symple ⁊and coy
Here grettest othe was but by seynt loy
And she was clepid ma dame Englentyne
Ful wel . she song the seruyse of dyuyne
Entunyd in hir voyce nose ful semely
And frenssh sho spak ful fayre and fetysly .
As aftyr the scole of Stratteford atte bowe
For frenssh of Paryssh was to hir vnknowe
At the mete wel taught was she with all
She leete no morsel fro hir lippes fall
Ne wet hire fingres in hire sauce depe
Weele couthe she cary a morsell and wel kepe
That no drope shul falle vppon hir breest
In courtasye was sette ful mekil hire lyst
Here ouer lyppe wiped she ouer so clene
That in here coppe ther was no forthyng sene
Of greet ; whane she had dronke her draught
Ful semly aftyr hir mete she raught
And sekirly she was of grete disport
And ful pleasaunt and amyabil of port
And peynyd here for to countyrfeet cheere
Of court ; to be estatly of manere
And to be holdyn digne of Reuerence
But for to spekyn of hir conscience
She was so charitable and so pytouse
Sho wold wepe yif that she saugh a mouse
Caught in a trappe ; yif yt were ded or bleede
Smale houndys had she þat did fede
With rostid flessh or mylk or wastil brede
But sore wept she yif one of hem were dede
Or yif men smot yt with a yerde smert
And al was conscience and tendre hert
Ful semly here wympil pynchid was
Hir nose tretys hir eyen grey as glas
Hir mouthe ful smal and therto soft and reed
But sykirly she had a fayr forhed
It was almost a spanne brod I trowe
For hardily she was not vndirgrowe
Ful fetyse was hire cloke as I was war
Of smal coral aboute hir necke she bar
A payre of bedys gaudeed al with grene
And theron heng a broche of gold ful shene
On whiche furst was wryten a crownyd .A.
And aftyr Amor vincit omniA .
AN othir Nonne with hire hadde she
That was her chapeleyn ⁊and preestez thre ;
A monk ther was a fayr for þe maystry
An outryder that louyd venery
A manly man to be an abbot hable
Ful many a deynte hors had he in stable
And when he rode men myght his brydel here
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as dooth the chapell belle
There as this lord was keper of the celle
The reule of seynt maure or of seynt benyt
Be cause that yt was old and sumdel streyt
This ilke monke leet olde thyngez pace
And held aftir the newe world the space
He yaf not of that text a pullid hen
That seith that hunters were not holy men
Ne that a monke that is rekkelesse
Ys likenyd to a fissh that is watirlesse
This is to sey a monk out of his cloystre
But thilk tixt he thought not wurþ an oystre
And I seyd his opynyon was good
What shuld he stody and make hym self wood
Vppon a book in cloystre alway to poure
Or swynkyn with his handys and labour
As Augustyn biddith how shal þe world be suyd
Lat augustyn haue his swynk to hym reseruyd
Therfore he was a pricasoure a right
Grehoundis he hadde as swyft as foul in flight
Of pryckyng and of huntyng for the hare
Was al his lust for no spensez wold he spare
I saugh his sleuys purfilyd at the hand
With gryce and that the fynest of a land
And for to festyn his hood vndir his chyn
He had of gold wrought a ful curyous pyn
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His hede was ballid that shon as any glas .
And eke his face as he had been anoynt
He was a lord ful fat and in goode poynt
His eyen steepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemyd as a fourneyce of a lede
His botys souple his hors in gret astate
Now certaynly he was a fayr plate
He was not pale as a forpynyd gost
A fat swan louyd he best of any rost
His palfray was als brown as a bery
A frere there was a wantoıı̄un ⁊and a mery
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure is non þat can
So mekil of daliaunce and fayre language
He hadde made ful many a mariage
Of yong wommen of his owne cost
Vnto his ordre he was a noble post
Ful wel belouyd and familiar was he
With frankeleyns oủer/real in the cuntre
And with wurthi men in the town
For he hadde power of confessyon
As seid hym self more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licencyat
Ful swetly herd he confessyoun
And plesaunt was in his absolucyon
He was a visy man to gif penaunce
There as he wist to haue a good pytaunce
For to pouer ordre mony for to gyue
Is signe that a man is wel shryue
For yif he gaf he durst make his avaunt
He wist wel that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so herd is of his hert
He may not wepe al though hym sore smert
Therfor in stede of wepyng and prayers
Men most gyue siluer vnto the pouere frerys
His tipet was ay farsid ful of knyfes
And pynnys for to gyff fayre wyfes
And certaynly he had a mery I
Wel couthe he syngeand play on a rote
Of yeddyngez he bar vttirly the pryce
His necke was white as is the floure delice
Therto he strong was as a champyon
He knew the taủer/renes wel and eủer/rey town
And euerych hosteler and tapister
Bettyr than a lazar or a begger
For to swich a wurthi man as he
Accordid not as by his faculte
To haue with seek lazers acqueyntaunce
Yt is not honest yt may not avaunce
For to dele with no suych pouerayle
But al with ryche and sellers of vitayle
And oủer/real ther as ꝓprofyte shuld ryse
Curtayse he was and lowely of seruyse
Ther was no man nowgher so vertuous
He was the best begger of al his hous
For þough a wydew had not a sho
So plesaunt was his In principio
Yit wold he haue a ferthyng or he went
His purchace was wel better than his rent
And rage he couth right as yt were a whelp
In louedayez ther couth he mekil help
For ther he was not like a cloystrer
With a thredbare cope like a pouer scoler
But he was like a mayster or a pope
Of double wurstede was his semycope
Þat rowndid as abell cam out of presse
Sumwhat he lispid for his wantonesse
To make his englissh sweete vppon his tonge
And in his harpyng when he had songe
His eyen twynklyd in his hede a right
As don the sterrys in the frosty nyght
This wurthy lymytour was clepid hoberd
A marchaund was þ̉er/re wiþ a forked berd
In motle and hye on hors he satte
Vppon his hed a flaundres beuer hatte
His botys claspid fayre and fresshly
His resouns he spak ful solempnely
Sownyng alwey to the encrese of his wynnyng
He wold the feeth fee were kept for any thyng
Betwix Medilburgh and Orwell
Wel couth he in eschaunge sheldes sell
This wurthy man ful wel his wyt besette
Ther wist no wight that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủer/renaunce
With his bargayns and his cheuysshaunce
For soothe he was a wurthi man with alle
But sooth to seyn I not how men hym calle
A clerk ther was of Oxenford also
That to logyk had long y go
Als lene was his hors as is a Rake
And he was not right fatte I vndirtake
But lokyd holow and therto sobyrly
Ful thredbare was his ouerest courtpy
For he hadde yit getyn hym no benefyce
Ne was so worldly for to haue office
For hym vas leuer haue at his beddis hed
Twenty goode bookys clad in blak and red
Of aristotle and of his philosophie
Than Robys ryche or fithell or gay sautrye
But al be that he was a philosophre
Yit hadde he but lytell gold in Cofre
But al that he myght of his freendys hent
On bookes and on lernyng he yt spent
And besily gan for the soules prey
Of hem that hym gaf therwith did to scoley
Of study took he most cure and most hede
Not a wurd spak he more than was neede
And that was seid in fourme and Reuerence
And short and quyk and ful of hye sentence
Sownyng in moral vertu was his speche
And gladly wold he lerne and gladly teche
A sergeaunt of lawe boþe war ⁊and wise
That oftyn had ben at the ꝑper/paruyse
Ther was also ; ful riche of excellence
Discreet he was and of gret Reuerence
Hym semyd such his wurdys were so wise
Iustyce he was ful oftyn in assise
By patent and by pleyn commyssyon
For his science and his hye Renown
Of fees and Robes had he manyon
So gret a purchasour was nowher non
Al was fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not be enfecte
Nowher so besy a man as he ther nas
And yit he semyd beseer than he was
In termes had he cases and domys alle
That fro the tyme of kyng willyam did falle
Therto he couthe endyte and make a thing
Ther couth no wight pinche at his wryting
And euery statute couth he pleyn by Rote
He rode but homly in a medle cote
Gird with a seynt of silk with barrys smale
Of his aray telle I no lenger tale
A frankeleyn was in his company
White was his berd as ys þe dayesy
Of his complexion he was sanguyne
Wel louyd he by the morwe a sop in wyne
To lyue in delyte was euer his wone
For he was epicurus owne sone
That hadde opynyon playn þat delyte
Was hur verray felicitee perfyte
An houshalder and þat a gret was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his cuntre
His bred his ale was alway aftyr one
A bettyr man was nowher non
Without bake mete was neuyr in his house
Of fissh and flessh and that so plenteuouse
That the disshes were filled to the brinke
It snowyd in his hous of mete and drynke
Aftir the sundry sesons of the yeere .
So chaungid he his mete and his sopere
Ful many fatte partrike had he in muwe
And many a breme and luce had he in stue
Wo was his cook but yif his sauce were
Poynaunt and fast redy in al his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alway
Stood redy coueryd al the long day
At sessyouns ther was he lord and syre
Ful ofte tyme had he been knyght of þe shyre
An anlas and a gisper al of sylk
Hengyd at his girdel whyte as morn mylke
And a shereue had he be and countour
Was nowher such a wurthy vauasour
An haberdassher and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a Tapyser
And thei were clad al in one lyuere
Of a ful solempne and gret fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe here gere pykid was
Here knyfes were chapid not with bras
But al with siluer wrought clene and wel
Here girdles and here pouchis euerydel
We semyd ich of hem a fayre burgeyse
To syttyn in a yeldhalle on a deyse
Euerich for wisdam that he can
Was shappely for to be an alderman
For catell had thei ynough and rent
And eke here wyfes wold therto wel assent
And ellis certayn were thei to blame
It is ful fayre to be clepid madame
And gone to vigilees al be foore
And haue a mantyl ryally y bore
A Cook thei hadde with þem for þe nonys
To boyle the chikenes and þe marybonys
And powdre marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wel couth he knowe a draught of londoıı̄un ale
He couth rost and sethe boyle and frye
Makyn mortrews and wel make a pye
But grete harme was yt as semyd me
That on his shyn a morymal hadde he
For blankmaunger made he at the best
A shipman was þ̉er/re wonyng ferre by west
For ought I wot he was of derthmouþe
He rode vppon a Rounsy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A dagger hengyng on a lace had he
About his necke vndir his arme down
The somer hote hadde made his hewe al brown
And certanly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draught of wyne had he drawe
Fro burdews ward whil that þe chapman sleepe
Of nyce conscience took he no keepe
Yif that he faught and had the hygher hand
By water he sent hem hom to euery land
But of his craftys to rekkyn wel his tydes
His streme and his daungers hym besides
His harbarwe his moone lod menage
Ther was non suych fro hul to cartage
Hardy he was and wyse to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berd been shake
He knewe alle the hauenys als thei were
Fron gotland to the gappe of fynestere
And euery cryke in bretayn and in spayne
His barge was clepid the mawdelayne
Utth vs ther was a doctoᵘur of fysike
In al this world is non hym like
To speke of fysyke and of surgerye
For he was groundid in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a ful gret deel
In hourys by his magyk naturel
Weel couthe he fortunen the ascendent
Of his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of euery maledye
Were yt of hete cold moyst or drye
And where thei gendrid and of what humoᵘ
He was a verray ꝑper/parfyte practesour
The cause he knew and of the harme the roote
And by than the syke man hauys his boote
Ful redy had he his apotacarijs
To sendyn hym his draggez and his electuarijs
For ich of hem made othir for to wynne
Theyre frendsship was not newe to begynne
Wel knewe he the olde esculapius
And discordeys and eke rusius
Old ypocras hoolly and galien
Serapyon rasis and auyseyn
Aủer/reoys damastyn and constantyn
Bernard gatistiden and gilbertyn
Of his dyete mesurable was he
For yt was not of no suꝑper/parfluyte
But gret norisshyng and digestible
His study was but litell in the bible
In sanguyne and in pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata and with sendal
And yit he was but easy of dispence
He kept that he wan in the pestilence
For gold in phisyk is accordiall
Therfore he louyd gold in especiall
A good wyfe ther was of beside bathe
But she was sumdel def ⁊and þᵗat was skaþe
Of clothe makyng she hadde suych an haunt
She passid them of ypris and of gaunt
In al the parissh wyfe ne was ther non
That to the offeryng beforne hir shuld gon
And yif ther did certayn so wroth was she
That sho was out of al charyte
Here coủer/rechiefs ful fyn were of grounde
I durst swere thei weyed ten pounde
That on a sunday were vppon hir hed
Hir hosys were of fyn skarlet red
Ful strayte ytyed and shoon ful newe
Bold was hir face and fayr of hewe
She was a wurthy womman al hir lyue
Husbandys at the kirke doore had she fyue
Withoutyn othir company in youthe
But therof nedith not to speke as nouthe
And thryes had she been at Ierm
She hadde passid many a straunge strem
At Rome she hadde ben and at boloyne
In galice at seynt Iames and at coloyne
She couthe mekil of wandryng by the way
Gat tothid was she soothly for to say
Vppon an amblour soothly she satte
Wympled wel and on hir hed an hatte
Als brod as is a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantell aboute hir hippes large
And on hir feet a payre of spurrys sharpe
In felawship wel couthe laugh and karpe
Of Remedyes of loue she knewe ꝑper/parchaunce
For she couthe of that art the olde daunce
A good man ther was of Religion
And was a pouer ꝑper/parson of a toun
But riche he was of holy thought ⁊and werk
He was also a lernyd man a clerk
That crystis gospell truly wold teche
His parisshens deuoutly wold he preche
Benigne he was and wondyr diligent
And in aduersite ful pacient
And such he was prouyd ofte sythis
Ful loth were hym to cursyn for his tithis
But rathir wold he gynyn out of doute
To his pouer parisshens al a boute
Of his offryng and of his substaunce
He couthe in lytill thing haue sufficeaunce
Wyde was his parissh and houses fer a sundre
But he left not for Reyn ne for thondre
In sieknesse and myscheef for to visite
The ferthest in his parissh mychel and lyte
Vppon his feet and his hand a staffe
Out of the gospell the wurdes he caught
This noble ensaunple to his sheep he yaf
That furst he wrought and aftirward he taught
And this figure he addid yit therto
That yif gold ruste what shal Iren do
For yif a preest be foul on whom we trust
No wondre is lewde men to rust
And shame yt is yif a preest take keep
A shytten shepherd and a clene sheep
Wel aught a preest ensaunple for to yif
By his clennesse how that his sheep shuld lif
He sette not his benefice to hyre
And left his sheep encombred in the myre
And ranne to londoıı̄un to seynt powlys
To seke hym a chauntry for soules
Or with a brothir hed to be withold
But dwellid at home and kepid his fold
So that the wolf made yt not myscary
He was a shepherd and no thing a mercenary
And though he holy were and vertuous
He was not to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his teching discret and benygne
To drawe folk to heuyn by clennesse
By good ensaunple this was his besynesse
But yif it were any ꝑper/parsone obstynate
What euer he were of high or lowe estate
Hym wolde he snybbe sharply for the nonys
A bettyr prest I trow nowher non is
He wayted aftir no pompe ne Reuerence
Ne makid hym a spiced conscience
But cristes lore and his apostlys twelue
He taught but furst he folwid yt hym self
Uith hym ther was a plowman his broþ̉er/re
Þat had lad of dung many a fothir
A trew swynkere and a good was he
Lyuyng in pees and ꝑper/parfyte charyte
God louyd he best with al his hool herte
At alle tymes þough hym gamyd or smerte
And than his neighboᵘur right as hym self
He wold thressh and therto dyke and delf
For cristis sake for euery pouer wight
Without hire yif yt lay in his myght
His tithis payed he bothe fayre and wel
Bothe of his propre swynk and his catel
In a tabbard he rode vppon a mere
Ther was also a Reue and a mylnere
A sompnoᵘur and a pardoner also
A manciple and my self ther wer no mo
The mylner was a strong carl for the nonys
Ful big he was of brawne and eke of bonys
That preuyd wel for oueral ther he cam
At wrastlynges he had alway the Ram
He was short shuldred brod and thikke knarre
Ther was no dore þat he ne wold haue of harre
Or breke yt with a rennyng with his hed
His berd as any heaf fox was red
And therto brod as þough yt were a spade
Vppon the coppe right of his nose he hade
A wert and theron stood a tufte of herys
Rede as the birstles of a sowys erys
His nose thrilles blak were and wyde
A swerd and a bokeler he bare by his side
His mouthe as gret as was fourneyce
He was a iangler and a galiardece
And that was most of synne and harlotryez
Wel couth he stele corne and tolle thryes
And yit he hadde a thombe of gold ꝑper/parde
A white cote and a blew hood werid he
A bagge pipe wel couthe he blowe and sown
And therwithal he brought vs out of town
A gentil maunciple was þ̉er/re of a temple .
Of whiche alle catoᵘurs myght take exēmple .
For to be wise in byeng of vitayle
For whetthir þat he payed or took by tayle
Algate he waityd so in his acate
That he was ay beforn and in good estate
Now is it not that of god a ful gret grace
That suych a lewd mannys wyt shal pace
The wisdam of an hepe of lernyd men
Of maystres hadde he mo than thries ten
That weren of lawe expert and curyous
Of which ther were a dusseyn in that hous
Wurthi to be stiward of rent and land
Of any lord that is in England
To make hym lyue by his ꝓpropre good
In honour detles but he yif he were wood
Or lyue als scarsly right as hym list desire
And hable for to help al a shire
In any case that myght falle or happe
And yit this maunciple sette þ̉er/re alder cappe .
The Reue was a sklendre colerik man
His berd was shaue as smoþᵉ as any ban
His heer was by his eerys ful rounde shorn
His toppe was dokkid like a preest beforn
Ful long were his legges and ful lene
Like to a rake ther was no calf sene
Wel couth he kepe a garner or a bynne
Ther was non auditoᵘur couth of hym wynne
Wel wist he by the drought and by þe rayne
The yeeldyng of his sted and of his grayne
His lordis sheep his mete his deyrye .
His swyne his hors his stood and his pultrye .
Was hoolly in this Reuys gouernyng
And by his couenant yaf he the rekkenyng
Sythen that his lord was twenty yeer of age .
Ther couth no man bring hym in arrerage .
Ther nas bailly ne heerde ne othir hyne
But that he knew his sleight and his engyne
Thei were aferd of hym as of the deth
His wonyng was ful fayr vppon an heth
With grene trees shadwid was his place
He couth bettyr than his lord purchace
Ful richely he was astoryd pryuyly
His lord wel couth he please soothly
To yyf and lene hym of his owne good
And haue a thank and yit a cote and an hood
In yougthe he lernyd had a good mystere
He was a wel good wright and a carpentere
This Reue satte vppon a wel good stotte
That was a pomely gray and hight scotte .
A long surcote of pers vppon he hadde
And by his side he bare a rusty blade .
Of Northfolk was this Reue of which I telle .
Beside a town men clepyn haldiswelle .
Tukkid he was as is a frere a boute
And euyr he rode the hyndrest in the route .
A sompnour was ther wᵗith us was in þᵗat place .
That had a fayre rod cherubyn face .
For sausflem he was with eyen narwe .
As hoot he was and likerous as sparwe
With scalid blak and pillid berd
With his visage childern were aferd
Ther nas quyk siluer litarge ne burnston
Borace ceruse ne oyle of tartare non
Ne oynement that wold clense and byte .
That hym myght help of his whelkis white
Ne of knobbis syttyng on his chekis
Wel louyd he garleek onyouns and leekis
And for to drynke red wyn strong as blood
Than wold he speke and crye as he were wood
And when he wel dronkyn had the wyne
Than wold he speke no wurd but latyne .
A fewe termys had he two or thre
That he hadde lernyd out of sum decre .
No wondir is he herd yt al the day
And yee knowen wel how that a Iay
Can clepyn watte als wel as can the pope
But who so couth in othir thinges grope
Than had he spendid al his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wold he crye
He was a gentil harlot and a kynde
A bettir felawe shuld no man fynde
He wold suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felawe to haue his concubyne
A twelmoneth and excuse hym at the fulle .
Ful pryuely a fynch couth he pulle .
And yif he fond owher a good felawe .
He wold techyn hym to haue non awe
In such case of the Archedekyn curse
But yif a mannys soule werin his purse
For in his purse he shuld punysshid be
Purse is the Archedekyns helle said he
But wel I wot he lyed right in dede
Of curse ought euery gilty man to drede
For curse wil sle right as assoylyng sauyth
And also war hym of a significauit
In daunger hath he at his owne guyse .
The yonge girles of the diocyse
And knewe hir counsel and was her reed
A garland hadde sette vppon his heed
Als gret as yt were for an ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of a cake
Uith hym ther rode a ioly pardonere
Of Rounceuale his frend ⁊and his feere
That streight was comyn fro þe court of Rome
Ful lowd he sang come hider loue to me
This sompnoᵘur bar to hym a stiffe burdoun
Was neuyr trumpe of half so gret a sown
This ꝑper/pardoner had here a yelow as any wex
But smoth yt heng as dooth a stryke of flex
By ouncys heng his lokkis þat he hadde
And therwith he his gret shulders spradde
But thynne yt lay by culpouns on and on
And hood for iolytee werid he non
For yt was trussid vppon his walette
Hym thought he rode al on the newe gette
Discheuelee saue his cappe he rode al bare
Suych a glasing eye had he . as an hare
A veronicle had he suwed on his cappe
His walet beforn hym in his lappe
Bretful of ꝑper/pardon comyn fro Rome al hoot
A voice he hadde as smal as hath a goot
No berd had he ne neuyr shuld haue
As smothe yt was as yt were late shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his craft from berwyk vnto ware
Ne was ther suych an othir ꝑper/pardoner
For in his male he had a pilowbeer
Whiche as he said was oure ladyes vayle
He saide he hadde a gobet of the sayle
That seynt petir hadde when he went
Vppon the see til Ihu criste hym hent
He hadde a crosse of latoun ful of stonys
And in a glasse he hadde pigges bonys
But with thise reliques whan þat he fond
A pouer ꝑper/parson dwellyng vppon lond
Vppon a day he gat hym more moneye
Than that ꝑper/parson gat in monethis tweye
And thus with feynyd flatery and iapis
He made the ꝑper/parson and the poeple his apys
But truly to tellyn at the last
In the chirche he was a noble ecclesiast
Wel couthe he rede a lesson or a story
But althirbest he song an offertory
For wel he wist whan that song was sunge
He most preche and wel avise his tunge
To wynne siluer as he wel cowde
Therfor he song the merilyer and loude
Now haue I told yow shortly in a clause
Þe state þe aray þe nombre and þe cause
Whi that assemblid was this company
In southwerk at this gentil hostelry
That hight the tabbard right by the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we bare vs that ilk nyght
Whan we were in þat hostelry alight
And aftir wil I telle of oure viage .
And al the Remanent of oure pilgrymage
But furst I pray yow of youre curtasye
That yee ne ret yt my vilanye
Though I pleynly speke in this mater
To telle yow her wurdys and her cheer
Ne though I speke her wurdis propirly
For this yee knowe al as wel as I
Who so shal telle a tale aftir a man
He mot reherce as nygh as euyr he can
Euery wurd yif yt lye in his charge
Þough he speke neủer/re so rudely and so large
Or ellis he mot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thyng or fynd wurdes newe
He may not spare al though he wer his broþ̉er/re
He mot als wel sey on wurd as othir
Criste spake ful brode in holy wrytte
And wel yee wit no vilany is yt
Eke plato seith who so can hym rede
The wurd mot been cosyn to the dede
Also I pray yow foryif yt me
Alle haue I not sette folk in her degree
Here in this tale as thei shuld stonde
My wyt is short yee may wel vndirstonde
GRet chere made oᵘur host vs euerichon
And to the soper sette we were a non
He seruyd vs with vitaile at the best
Strong was the wyne and wel drinke vs lest
A semly man our host was with alle
For to be a marshall of an halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A fayrer burgeys was þer non in chepe
Bold of his speche and wise and wel taught
And manhode hym lakkid right naught
Eke therto he was a mery man
And after soper to pleyen he began
And spak of myrthe among othir thyng
And whan that he had made oure rekkenyng
He said thus lo lordynges truly
Yee be to me right welcome hertily
For by my trouthe yif that I shal not lye
I saugh not this yeer so mery a companye
At onys in this herbarw as is now
Fayn wold I do yow myrthe wist I how
And of a myrthe I am right now be thought
To done yow ease and yt shal cost nought
Yee gon to Cauntyrbury god yow spede
The blisful martyr quyte yow youre mede
And wel I wot as ye gon by the way
Yee shape yow to talke and to play
For truly myrth ne comfort is non
To ryden by the way dombe as a ston
And therfore wil I make yow disport
As I seid erst and do yow comfort
And yif yow liketh al by one assent
For to stondyn at my Iuggement
As for to wirkyn as I shal yow say
To morwe whan yee ryden by the way
Now by my fadirs soule þat is ded
But yif yee be mery I wil lese myn hed
Hold vp youre handes without more speche
Oure counsel was not long for to seche
Vs thought yt not wurth to make yt wise
And grauntid hym without more aduyse
And bad hym sey his veredicte as hym lest
Lordynges now herkenyth for the best
But take yt not I pray yow to disdeyn
This is the poynt to speke short and pleyn
That ich of yow to short with oure way
In this viage shal telle vs talys tway .
To Cauntirbury ward I mene yt so .
And homward he shal telle vs othir two
Of aventurys that whilom haue falle
And whiche of yow that berys hym best of alle
That is to seyn that tellis in this case
Tales of best sentence and most solace
Shal haue a soper at oure alther cost
Here in this place sittyng by this post
When that we comyn ageyn fro Caunt̉er/rebury
And for to make yow the more mery
I wil my self goodly with yow ryde
Right at myn owne cost and be yoᵘur guyde
And who so wil my Iuggement with say
Shal pay al that we spende by the way
And yif yee vouchesauff þat it be so
Telle me anon without wurdys mo
And I wil erly shape me therfore
This thing was grauntid and othis swore
With ful glad hert and prayed hym also
That he wold vouchesauff for to do so
And that he wold be oure gouernou9
And of oure tales Iuge and be Reportour
And sette a soper at a certeyn pryce
And we wil be rulyd at his deuyse
In heigh and lowe and thus by on assent
We haue accordid to this Iuggement
And thervppon the wyne was fet anon
We drank and to rest went ichon
Without any lenger tareyng
At morwe when that day gan spryng
Vp rose oure host and was oure althir cokke
And gedird vs to gedir al in a flokke
And forth we ryden a litil more than a pace
Vn to the wateryng of seynt thomas
And ther oure host began his hors arest
And said herkenyth lordyngez yif yow lest
Yee wit youre forward and yt yow recorde
Yif euynsong and morwe song accorde
Let se now who shal telle the furst tale
As euyr mot I drynk wyne or ale
Who so be rebelle to my Iuggement
Shal pay for al that by the way is spent
Now drawith cutte or we ferther twynne
He that hauys the shortest shal begynne
ʆser/sir knyght qd he my mayster and my lord
Now drawe cutte for that is myn accord
Comyth neer quoth he my lady prioresse
And yee ʆser/sir clerk lat be your shamefastnesse
Ne studyeth not lay hand to euery man
A non to drawyn euery wight began
And shortly to tellyn as yt was
Were yt by auenture or sort or case
The sooth is this the cutte fel on þe knyght
Of which ful glad was eủer/rey wight
And telle he most his tale as was resoun
By forward and by composycyoun
As yee haue herd what nedith wurdis mo
And whan this good man saugh þat yt was so
As he that was wyse and obedient
To kepe his forward by his fre assent
He said sythen that I shal begyn the game
What welcome be thou cut on goddis name
Now lete vs ryde and herkynyth what I say
And that wurd we ryden forth oure way
And he began with right a mery chere
His tale and said on this manere
Iam que domos patrias stichite post aspera gentis Premia laurigero laurigero et cetera .
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten

div.l: (base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge

div.l: (base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste

(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
(base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun

div.l: (base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
(base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
(base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe

div.l: (base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
(base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele

div.l: (base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
(base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde

div.l: (base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
(base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
(base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
(base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite wook and sterte
(base) Now trewely / how sore that me smerte
(base) Quod he / to Atthenes right now wol I fare
(base) Ne for the drede of deeth / shal I nat spare
(base) To se my lady / that I loue and serue
(base) In hir presence / I recche nat to sterue
(base) ¶ And with that word / he caughte a greet Mirour
(base) And saugh / that chaunged was al his colour

(base) And right anoon / it ran hym in his mynde
(base) That sith his face / was so disfigured

(base) Lyue in Atthenes / eueremoore vnknowe
(base) And seen his lady / wel ny / day by day

(base) To Atthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
(base) And to the Court he wente vpon a day
(base) And at the gate / he profreth his seruyse
(base) To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuyse
(base) ¶ And shortly / of this matere / for to seyn
(base) He fil in office / with a Chambreleyn
(base) The which / that dwellyng was wᵗith Emelye
(base) For he was wys / and koude soone espye
(base) Of euery seruant which that serueth here
(base) Wel koude he / hewen wode / and water bere
(base) For he was yong . and myghty for the nones
(base) And ther to / he was strong and byg of bones
(base) To doon / what any wight kan hym deuyse
(base) A yeer / or two / he was in this seruyse
(base) Page of the chambre / of Emelie the brighte
(base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte
(base) ¶ But half so wel biloued a man / as he
(base) Ne was ther neuere in Court of his degree
(base) He was so gentil / of condicioun
(base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
(base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
(base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
(base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse
(base) But Palamon / that loue destreyneth so

div.l: (base) And eek ther to / he is a prisoner
(base) Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yer
(base) Who koude ryme / in englissh proprely
(base) His martirdom / for sothe it am noght I
(base) Therfore I passe / as lightly / as I may
(base) ¶ It fil / that / in that seuenthe yeer of May
(base) I wylle not taire yow alle the day
(base) The thridde nyght . as olde bokes seyn
(base) That al this storie / tellen moore pleyn
(base) Were it by auenture / or destynee
(base) As whan a thyng is shapen / it shal be
(base) That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun
(base) By helpyng of a freend / brak his prisoun
(base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go
(base) For he hadde yeue / his Gailler drynke so
(base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn
(base) With Nercotikes / and opye / of Thebes fyn / /
(base) That al that nyght . thogh that men wolde hym shake
(base) The Gailler sleep / he myghte noght awake
(base) ¶ And thus he fleeth / as faste as euere he may
(base) The nyght was short and faste by the day
(base) That nedes cost he moste hymseluen hyde
(base) And til a groue / faste ther bisyde
(base) With dreedful foot thanne stalketh Palamoun
(base) For shortly / this was his opynyoun
(base) That in that groue / he wolde hym hyde al day
(base) And in the nyght thanne wolde he take his way
(base) To Thebesward / his freendes for to preye
(base) On Theseus / to helpe hym to werreye
(base) And shortly / outher he wolde lese his lyf /
(base) Or wynnen Emelie / vnto his wyf
(base) This is the effect and his entente pleyn
(base) ¶ Now wol I turne / to Arcite ageyn
(base) That litel wiste / how neigh that was his care
(base) Til that Fortune / hadde broght hym / in the snare
(base) ¶ The bisy larke / messager of day
(base) Salueth in hir song the morwe gray
(base) And firy Phebus / riseth vp so brighte
(base) That al the Orient . laugheth of the lighte
(base) And with his stremes / dryeth in the greues
(base) The siluer dropes / hangynge on the leues
(base) And Arcita / that in the Court roial
(base) With Theseus / is Squyer principal
(base) Is risen / and looketh on the murye day
(base) And for to doon / his obseruance to May
(base) Remembrynge / on the point of his desir
(base) He on a Courser / startlynge as the fir
(base) Is riden in to the feldes / hym to pleye
(base) Out of the Court . were it a myle / or tweye
(base) And to the groue / of which that I yow tolde
(base) By auenture / his wey he gan to holde
(base) To maken hym / a gerland of the greues
(base) Were it of wodebynde / or hawethorn leues
(base) And loude he soong . ayein the sonne shene
(base) May / with alle thy floures / and thy grene
(base) Wel come be thow / faire fresshe May
(base) In hope / that I som grene gete may
(base) And from his courser / with a lusty herte
(base) In to the groue / ful hastily he sterte
(base) And in a path / he rometh vp and doun
(base) Ther as by auenture / this Palamoun
(base) Was in a bussh / that no man myghte hym se
(base) For soore afered / of his deeth was he
(base) No thyng knew he / that it was Arcite
(base) God woot he wolde haue trowed it ful lite
(base) But sooth is seyd / go sithen many yeris
(base) That feeld hath eyen / and the wode hath erys
(base) It is ful fair / a man to bere hym euene
(base) For alday meeten men / at vnset steuene
(base) Ful litel woot Arcite / of his felawe
(base) That was so neigh / to herknen al his sawe
(base) For in the bussh / he sitteth now ful stille
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / hadde romed al his fille
(base) And songen al the roundel lustily
(base) In to a studie / he fil sodeynly
(base) As doon thise louerys / in hir queynte gerys
(base) Now in the crop / now down in the brerys
(base) Now vp / now down / as boket in a welle
(base) Right as the friday / soothly for to telle
(base) Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
(base) Right so / kan gery Venus ouercaste
(base) The hertes of hir folk . right as hir day
(base) Is gerful / right so chaungeth she array
(base) Selde is the friday / al the wike ylike
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite hadde songe / he gan to syke
(base) And sette hym down / withouten any moore
(base) Allas quod he / that day / that I was bore
(base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan

div.l: (base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
(base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde
(base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
(base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wᵗith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe
(base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
(base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
(base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
(base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.
(base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe
(base) Or he moot sle me / if that me myshappe
(base) So ferden they / in chaungyng of hir hewe
(base) As fer / as euerich / oother of hem knewe
(base) ¶ Ther nas no good day / ne no saluynge
(base) But streight withouten word / or rehersynge
(base) Euerich of hem / heelp for to armen oother
(base) As frendly / as he weere / his owene brother
(base) And after that with sharpe speres stronge
(base) They foynen / ech at oother / wonder longe
(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun
(base) In his fightyng were a wood leoun
(base) And as a crewel Tygre / was Arcite
(base) As wilde boores / gonnen they to smyte
(base) That frothen / whit as foom / for Ire wood
(base) Vp to the Anclees / foghte they in hir blood
(base) And in this wise / I lete hem fightyng dwelle
(base) And forth I wole / of Theseus yow telle
(base) ¶ The destynee / Ministre general
(base) That executeth / in the world oueral
(base) The purueiance / that god hath seyn biforn
(base) So stroong it is / that thogh the world hadde sworn
(base) The contrarie of a thyng by ye / or nay
(base) Yet som tyme / it shal fallen on a day
(base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer
(base) For certeinly / oure appetites heer
(base) Be it of werre / or pees / or hate / or loue
(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May
(base) That in his bed / ther daweth hym no day
(base) That he nys clad / and redy for to ryde
(base) With hunte and horn / and houndes hym bisyde
(base) For in his huntyng hath he swich delit
(base) That it is / al his ioye and appetit
(base) To been hymself the grete hertes bane
(base) For after Mars / he serueth now Diane
(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this
(base) And Theseus / with alle ioye and blys
(base) With his ypolita / the faire queene
(base) And Emelie / clothed al in greene
(base) On huntyng be they riden roially
(base) And to the groue / that stood ful faste by
(base) In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
(base) Duc Theseus / the streighte wey hath holde
(base) And to the launde / he rideth hym ful right
(base) For thider was the hert wont haue his flight
(base) And ouer a brook / and so forth on his weye
(base) This duc / wol han a cours at hym / or tweye
(base) With houndes swiche / as that hym list comaunde
(base) And whan this Duc. was come vnto the launde
(base) Vnder the sonne he looketh / and anon
(base) He was war / of Arcite and Palamoun
(base) That foghten breme / as it were boles two
(base) The brighte swerdes / wenten to and fro
(base) So hidously / that with the leeste strook
(base) It semed / as it wolde felle an ook
(base) But what they weere / no thyng he ne woot
(base) This Duc his courser / with the spores smoot
(base) And at a stert he was bitwix hem two
(base) And pulled out a swerd / and cryed hoo
(base) Namoore / vpon peyne / of lesyng of youre heed
(base) By myghty Mars / he shal anon be deed
(base) That smyteth any strook / that I may seen
(base) But telleth me / what myster men ye been
(base) That been so hardy / for to fighten heer
(base) Withouten Iuge / or oother officer
(base) As it weere in a lystes roially
(base) ¶ This Palamon / answerde hastily
(base) And seyde / sire / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And seide sire what nedith wordes moo
(base) We haue the deeth disserued / bothe two
(base) Two woful wrecches been we / two caytyues
(base) That been encombred / of oure owene lyues
(base) And as thow art a rightful lord and Iuge
(base) Ne yif vs / neither mercy ne refuge
(base) But slee me first. for seinte charitee
(base) But slee my felawe eek as wel as me
(base) Or slee hym first. for thogh thow knowe it lite
(base) This is thy mortal foo / this is Arcite
(base) That fro thy lond / is banysshed on his heed
(base) For which / he hath deserued to be deed
(base) For this is he / that cam vnto thy yate
(base) And seyde / that he highte Philostrate
(base) Thus hath he iaped thee / ful many a yeer
(base) And thow hast maked hym / thy chief Squyer
(base) And this is he / that loueth Emelye
(base) For sith the day is come / that I shal dye
