div.l: (base) I make pleynly / my confessioun
(base) That I am / thilke woful Palamoun
(base) That hath thy prisoun / broken wikkedly
(base) I am thy mortal foo / and it am I
(base) That loueth so hoote / Emelye the brighte
(base) That I wol dyen / present in hir sighte
(base) Wherfore I axe deeth / and my Iuwise
(base) But slee my felawe / in the same wise
(base) For bothe haue we / deserued to be slayn
(base) ¶ This worthy Duc answerde anoon agayn
(base) And seyde / this is a short conclusioun
(base) Youre owene mouth / by youre confessioun
(base) Hath dampned yow / and I wol it recorde
(base) It nedeth noght to pyne yow with the corde
(base) Ye shul be deed / by myghty Mars the rede
(base) ¶ The queene anoon / for verray wommanhede
(base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye
(base) And alle the ladies / in the compaignye
(base) Greet pitee was it / as it thoughte hem alle
(base) That euere swich a chaunce / sholde falle
(base) For gentil men they weere / of greet estaat
(base) And no thyng but for loue / was this debaat
(base) And sawe / hir blody wowndes / wide and soore
(base) And alle cryden / bothe lasse and moore
(base) Haue mercy lord / vpon vs wommen alle
(base) And on hir bare knees / adown they falle
(base) And wolde haue kist his feet ther as he stood
(base) Til at the laste / aslaked was his mood
(base) For pitee / renneth soone in gentil herte
(base) And thogh he first. for Ire quook and sterte
(base) He hath considred / shorthly in a clause
(base) The trespas of hem bothe / and eek the cause
(base) And althogh that his Ire / hir gilt accused
(base) Yet in his resoun / he hem bothe excused
(base) ¶ As thus / he thoghte wel that euery man
(base) Wol helpe hymself in loue / if that he kan
(base) And eek deliuere hymself / out of prisoun
(base) And eek his herte hadde compassioun
(base) Of wommen / for they wepten euere in oon
(base) And in his gentil herte / he thoghte anoon
(base) And softe vnto hymself / he seyde fy
(base) Vpon a lord / that wol haue no mercy
(base) But be a leoun bothe in word and dede
(base) To hem / that been in repentaunce and drede
(base) As wel / as to a proud despitous man
(base) That wol mayntene / that he first bigan
(base) That lord / hath litel of discrecioun
(base) That in swich caas / kan no dyuysioun
(base) But weyeth pryde / and humblesse / after oon
(base) And shortly / whan his Ire is thus agoon
(base) He gan to loken vp / with eyen lighte
(base) And spak thise same wordes / al on highte
(base) ¶ The god of loue / a benedicitee
(base) How myghty / and how greet a lord is he
(base) Agayns his myght . ther gayneth none obstacles
(base) He may be clepid a god / for his miracles
(base) For he kan maken / at his owene gyse
(base) Of euerich herte / as that hym list deuyse
(base) ¶ Lo here / this Arcite / and this Palamoun
(base) That quitly were / out of my prisoun
(base) And myghte haue lyued in Thebes roially
(base) And witen / I am hir mortal enemy
(base) And that hir deeth / lyth in my myght also
(base) And yet hath loue / maugree hir eyen two
(base) Broght hem hyder / bothe for to dye
(base) Now looketh / is nat that an heigh folye
(base) ¶ Who may been a fool / but if he loue
(base) Bihoold for goddes sake / that sit aboue
(base) Se how they blede / be they noght wel arrayed
(base) Thus hath hir lord / the god of loue ypayed
(base) Hir wages / and hir fees / for hir seruyse
(base) And yet they wenen / for to be ful wyse
(base) That seruen loue / for aught that may bifalle
(base) But this is yet the beste game of alle
(base) That she / for whom / they haue this Iolitee
(base) Kan hem therfore / as muche thank as me
(base) She woot namoore / of al this hoote fare
(base) By god / than woot a cokkow of an hare
(base) But al moot been assayed / hoot and coold
(base) A man moot been a fool / or yong or oold
(base) I woot it by myself / ful yoore agoon
(base) For in my tyme / a seruant was I oon
(base) And therfore / syn I knowe of loues peyne
(base) And woot how soore / it kan a man distreyne
(base) As he that hath been caught ofte in his laas
(base) I yow foryeue / al hoolly this trespas
(base) At requeste of the queene / that kneeleth heere
(base) And eek of Emelye / my suster deere
(base) And ye shal bothe anoon / vnto me swere
(base) That neuere mo / ye shal my contree dere
(base) Ne make werre vpon me / nyght nor day
(base) But been my freendes / in al that ye may

div.l: (base) I yow foryeue / this trespas euerydel
(base) And they hym sworen / his axing faire and wel
(base) And hym of lordshipe / and of mercy preyde
(base) And he hem graunteth grace / and thanne he seyde
(base) ¶ To speke of roial lynage / and richesse
(base) Thogh that she weere a queene / or a princesse
(base) Ech of yow bothe / is worthy doutelees
(base) To wedden whan tyme is / but nathelees
(base) I speke / as for my suster Emelye
(base) For whom / ye haue this stryf and Ialousye
(base) Ye woot your self. she may nat wedden two
(base) Atones / thogh ye fighten eueremo
(base) That oon of yow / al be hym looth / or lief
(base) He moot go pipen / in an yuy leef
(base) This is to seyn / she may nat now haue bothe
(base) Al be ye neuere so Ialous / ne so wrothe
(base) And for thy / I yow putte in this degree
(base) That ech of yow / shal haue his destynee
(base) As hym is shape / and herkneth in what wyse
(base) Lo here youre ende / of that I shal deuyse
(base) ¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioun
(base) Withouten any replicacioun
(base) If that yow liketh / take it for the beste
(base) That euerich of yow / shal goon where hym leste
(base) Frely / withouten raunsoun / or daunger
(base) And this day fifty wykes / fer ne neer
(base) Euerich of yow / shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
(base) Armed for listes / vp at alle rightes
(base) Al redy / to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght
(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou
(base) May with his hundred / as I spak of now
(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe
(base) And thus with good hope / and herte blythe
(base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde
(base) To Thebes / with olde walles wyde
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda
(base) The ordinaunce of lystys that Thesyus ordeynyd ⁊and cᵒ
(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily
(base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree
(base) He letted noght his felawe for to see
(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon

(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf
(base) Myn hertys lady cawser of my tene
(base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
(base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
(base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
(base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
(base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye
(base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) That soroweth and cryeth I wyl not lye
(base) Now wepith Emelye ⁊and waylith Palamon
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
(base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) As þat þ̉er/re was for deþ of þis Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) For sorwe of him þer weepeþ boþe child and man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
(base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
(base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
(base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be
(base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Explicit fabula Militis valde bona ⁊and incipit subsequenter prohemium fabule Molendinarij .
Uhan þᵗat the knyght haþ þus his tale told
In al þe rout ne was þer yong ne old
That he ne seid yt was a noble story
And wurthi to be drawe to memery
And namely the gentlys euerichon
¶ Oure host lough and swore so mot I gon
This goth a right vnbokelid is the male
Lat se now who shal telle an othir tale
For truly the gamyn is wel begonnyn
Now telle a tale ʆser/sir Monk yif þat ye kunne
Sum what to quyte with þis knyghtys tale
¶ The Myller that for dronkyn was al pale
So that vnneth vppon his hors he sat
He ne wold avalen nouthir hood ne hat
Ne abyde noman for his curtasye
But in Pilatys voice he began to crye
And swore by armys and by blood ⁊and bonys
I can a noble tale for the nonys
With whiche I wil now quyte þe knyght his tale
¶ Oure host saugh þat he was dronkyn of ale
And seid abyde Robyn abyde my leef brothir
Sum bettyr man shal telle vs furst an othir
Abyde and late vs wirchyn thryftily
By goddis soule quoth he that ne wil I
For I wil speke or ellys go my way
Oure host answerd telle on a deuylway
Thou art a fool thi wit is oủer/recome
Now herknyth quoth þe miller alle and some
But furst I make a protestāmcyon
I am dronke I knowe yt by my soun
And therfore yif that I speke amys or seye
Wyte yt the ale of suthwerk I yow preye
For I wil telle the legende and the lyfe
Bothe of a carpenter and of his wyfe
How that a carpenter Clerk hath set þe wrightꝭes cappe
¶ The Reue answerd and seid stynt thi clappe
Lat be thi lewde dronkyn haflotrye
It is a synne and eke a gret folye
To appayre any man or hym diffame
And eke to bringe wyfes in such fame blame
Thou may Inough of othir thingez sayn
¶ This dronkyn miller spak ful sone agayn
And seid leef brothir Oswalde
Who so hath no wyfe he is no cukwalde
But I sey not therfore þat thou art one
Ther been ful good wyfes many on
And euyr a Mˢ goode ageyns one badde
That knowis wel thi self but yif þou be madde
Whi art thou angry with my tale now
I haue a wyfe ꝑper/parde als wel as thou
Yit ne wold I for myn oxen in my plough
Take vppon me more than ynough
As deme of my self that I were one
I wil beleeue verray that I am non
An husband shuld not be inquisityfe
Of goddis pryuete ne of his wyfe
So he may fynde goddis foyson there
Of the Remanent nedith not to enquere
What shal I say but this dronken myllere
He ne wold his wurdis for no man forbere
But told his churlissh tale on his manere
Me for thynkith I shuld reherce yt here
And therfor euery gentil wight I yow pray
For goddis loue demyth not that I say
Of euyl entent for I mot Rehers
Her talys alle be thei bettyr or wers
Or ellis falsyn som of my matere
And therfore who so lyst yt not to here
Turne ouyr the leef and chese an othir tale
For he ynowgh shal fynde of gret ⁊and smale
Of storial that touchis gentilnesse
And eke moralyte and holynesse
Blamyth not me yif that yee chese a mys .
The myller is a cherl yee know we this
So was the Reue and othir many mo
And harlotrye thei toldyn bothe two .
Avisith yow but put me out of blame
And eke men shal not make ernest of game

l.hi: Explicit prohemium fabule molendinarij . Incipit subsequenter fabula

div.l: Uhilom þ̉er/re was duellyng at Oxenford
A Riche gnouf Chuffe þᵗat gestis had at bord
And of his craft he was a Carpenter
With hym ther was dwellyng a pouer scoler
Had þt lernyd art but al his fantasye
Was turnyd for to lerne astrologye
And couth a certeyn of conclusions
To demyn his interrogacions
Yif that men askyd hym in certeyn hourys
Whethir men shuld haue drought or shourys
Or yif men askid what shuld be falle
Of euery thing I may not rekkyn hem alle
This clerk was clepid hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he couthe and of solace
And therto he was sligh and ful pryuee
And like a mayde meke for to see
A chambre he hadde in that hostelry
Allone without any company
Ful fetysly dight with herbys swoote
And he hym self as sweet as is the roote
Of Liqueryse or any cetuale
Aftir his almogest and bookys gret ⁊and smale
Grayel myssal and holy Euᵃngel
Of Marke alkyndys wryten fayre and wel
The book that hight Non est iudicium
His astrelabyr and his albyon
And his instrumentys euerichou
Of smale and grete many on .
For to makyn his equacyouns
And Rootes of his verificaciouns
His astrelabyr hangid for his parte arte
His augrym stonys lay fayre for his arte apart
On shelfys couchid at his beddis hed
His presse coueryd with a faldyng red
And al aboue ther lay a gay sautre
On which he made on nyght melodee
So swetly that al the chambre rong
And angelus ad Virginem therin he song
Aftirward dide he song the kynges Note
Ful oft blissid was his mery throte
And thus this sweete clerk his tyme spent
Aftir his freendis fyndyng and his Rent
¶ This Carpenter had weddid a newe wyfe
Whiche that he louyd more þan his lyfe
Of xviij yeer she was of age
Ielouse he was and held hir narwe in cage
For she was wilde and yong and he was old

My modir gaf yt me so god me saue
Ful fyne yt is and therto ful wel graue
This wil I gyf the yif that thou me gisse
This Nicholas was rysen for to pisse
And thought he wold amende al the Iape
He shuld kysse his ers er that he escape
And vp the wyndow did he hastily
And out his hers he put pryuely
Ouer the buttok to the haunch bon
And therwith spak this absolon
Spek sweet brid I not not where thou art
This Nicholas anoıı̄un let flye a fart
Als gret as yt had been a thundir dent
And with that strok he was almost blent
And he was redy with his yren hoot
And nicholas a myddes the ers he smot
Of gos the skyn an handbrede about
The hot cultyr brent so his tout
And for yt smert he wend for to dye
As he were wood he gan for to crye
Help watir help for goddis hert
This carpenter out of his slombyr stert
And herd one crye watyr as he were wood
And thought allas now comyth Noes flood
He sette hym vp without wurdis mo
And with his axe he smot the cord a two
And doun he fel he fond neuthir to selle
Bred ne ale til he cam to the telle
Vppon the floore and there in swoune he lay
Vp styrt alison and also Nicholay
And cryen out and harrow in the strete
The Neighbours bothe smale and grete
In ther ran to gauryn on this man
That yit in swoune lay bothe pale and wan
For with the fal he hath brustyn his arm
But stande he most vn to his awne harm
For whan he spak he was anon born doun
With hend Nicholas and alisoun
Thei told eủer/rey man that he was wood
He was agast of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasye of his vanite
He had bought hym knedyng tubbys three
And had hem hengid in the roof aboue
And that he prayed hem for goddis loue
To syttyn in the roof pʳ company
The folk gan laugh at his fantasy
In to the roof thei looke and thei gape
And turnyd al his harme vnto a Iape
For what so this carpenter answerd
It was for nought no man his reson herd
With othis grete he was so born down
That he was holdyn wood in al the toun
For eủer/rey clerk anon right held with othir
Thei said the man was wood my leef brothir
That euery man gan laugh on his stryfe
Thus swyuyd was the carpenters wyfe
For al his kepyng and Ielousye
And absalon hath kissid hir nethir eye
And nicholay is skaldid in the toute
This tale is do god saue al this route

div.l: (base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete

Oure host saugh that þe bright sonne
The ark of his artificial had ronne
The vijte part and a half and an houre or more
And though he were were deepwere not deepwere not deep stert in lore
He wist yt was the xviijte day
Of april that is the messager to may
And saugh wel that the shadow of eủer/rey tree
Was in lengthe the same quantite
That was the body er hyt þat causid yt
And therfore by the shadow he took his wyt
That phebus shon so cleerly and so bright
Degrees was xlv clumbyn on hight
And for that day hath in that latitude
Yt was ten of the clocke he gan conclude
And sodenly he pright his hors aboute
Lordynges quoth he I warn yow al þe route
Verba hospitis ad totam comitiuam
The fourthe part of this day is gon
Now for the loue of god and of seynt Iohn
Lesith no tyme as ferforth as yee may
Lordynges the tyme wastith nyght and day
And stelith from vs what pryuely stelyng
And what thurgh negligence of oᵘur walkyng
As dooth the streem that turnys neuyr aga
Descendent from the mount in to the playn
Wel can senec and many a philosophire
Bewayle tyme more than gold in cofre
For losse of catel may recoueryd be
But losse of tyme shendys vs quoth he
It ne wil come agayn with outyn dreede
No more than a maydenys maydenhede
Whan she hath lost yt in hir wantonesse
Lat vs not mollen thus in ydelnesse
Verba hospitis ad seruientem Legis
I man of lawe quoth he so haue I blisse
Telle vs a tale anon as forward is
Yee been submyttid thurgh yoᵘur fre assent
To stondyn in this caas at my Iuggement
Acquytith yow now of your behest
Than haue yee doon your deuyr at þe lest
Responsio ad hospitem
Host quoth he par dieu I assent
To breke forward is not myn entent
Behest is dette and I wold hold yt fayn
Al my behest ; I can no bettyr sayn
For such law as an othir wryght
He shuld hym self vsen yt be right
Thus wil oure text but neủer/rethe les certayn
I can right now no thryfty tale sayn
Than Chauucers þough he can but lewdly
On metres or on rymyng craftily
Hath said hem in such englissh as he can
Of old tyme as knawys many a man
And yif he haue hem not said leef broth
In one book ; he has seid hem in an othir
For he told of louerys vp and doun
Mo than ouyde makys of mencyoun
In his epistlis that been ful olde
What shuld I telle hem sithen þei be tolde
In yougthe he made of ceys ⁊and alceon
And sithen hath he spokyn of eủer/reychon
Thise noble wyfes and thise louers eke
Who that wil his large volume seke
Clepid the seyntes lyfe of Cupide
There may he see the large woundes wyde
Of lucresse of babilon of cecily
The swerd of deth for the fals enny
The tree of Phillis for her demophon
The play of dyarnie and of Ermon
And of adrian and of Isiphilee
The bareyn yle standyng on the see
The leandre of his erro
The terys of helyn and eke the wo
O bryhed and eke ladmya
The cruelte of the queen medea
The litil childern hengyng bi the hals
For thi Iason that loue so fals
O penalope and also alcest
Your wyfhod he commendith at the best
But certanly no wurd wrytes he

That louyd hir owne brothir synfully
Of such historyes I say fy
Or ellis tyroellis of tyroellis of tyro appolloneus
How that the cursid kyng antiochus
Beraft his doughtyr of hir maydensedemaydenhedemaydensh
That is so horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he hir threw vppon the pauyment
And therfore he ful of aduysement
Nold neuer wryte in non of his sermons
Of suych vnkynde abhominacyouns
Ne I wil not reherce yif that I may
But of my tale how shal I do this day
Me were looth be lykkenyd doutles
To muses that men clepen prurides
Metamorphoseos wot what I mene
But neuyr the lesse I rekke not a bene
Þough I come aftir hem with hawe bake
I spek in prose and lete hem Rymes make
And with that wurd he with a sobrechere
Began his tale as yee shul aftir heere

O hateful harme condicyon of pouert
With thurst withthurst wyth colde withthurst wyth colde with hungyr so confoundid
To askyn help the shamys in thyn hert
Yif thou ne aske with nede þᵘ art so woundid
That verray neede vnwrappid al þⁱ wound hid
Maugreef thyn hede þᵘ most for indigence

¶ Thou blamyst cryste ⁊and saist ful bitterly
He mysꝑper/partith richesse temporal

And saist thou hauys to lytel ⁊and he hauys al
ꝐPer/Par fay seys thou sum tyme he rekne shal
Whan his tayle shal brenne in the gleede
For he not helpith nedeful in here nede
¶ Herkyn what is the menyng of the wise
Bettyr is to dye than haue indigence
For thyn owne neighboᵘur wil the despise
Yif thou be pouer ; fale welfare welfalre wel thi Reủer/reence
Yit of the wyse man take this sentence

¶ Yif thou be pouer thi brothir hatys the
And alle thi freendis fleen from the allas
O rich marchauntz ful of welthe bee yee
O noble prudent folk as in this caas
Your bagges be not fillid with ambez aas
But with siz synk that rennyth for yoᵘur chaunce
At Crystenmasse may yee merily daunce
¶ Yee seekyn londys seere for yoᵘur wynnyngez
As wysemen yee knowe al the estate

IN surrey som tyme therdwelliddwellidtherdwellid a company
Of chapman riche and þ̉er/reto sadde ⁊and trewe
That wyde where send hir spicery
⁊and clothis of gold and satanys riche of hewe
Here chaffare was so myghti ⁊and so newe
That euery wight had daynte for to chaffare
With hem ; and eke to byesele hembyesele hem of here ware
¶ Now fel yt so that the maystres of þᵗat sorte
Hath shapyn hem to Rome for to weende
Were yt for chapmanhod or for disporte
No oo messager wold theithei thider sende
But comen hem self to Rome this is þe eende
And in such place as thought hēm avauntage
For theire entent thei took her hebergage
¶ Soiournyd haue thise mchauntz in þᵗat toun
A certeyn ascerteyn time ascerteyn time as fel to theyre plesaunce
But so befel that excellent Renoun
Of the emperoᵘur doughtyr dam Custaunce
Expressid was with eủer/rey circumstaunce
To thise surryans mchauntz in such wyse
From day to day as I shal yow deuyse
¶ This was the comoun voice of eủer/rey man
ʆser/sir our Emperour of Rome god hym see
A doughtyr hath he that sithen þᵉ world began
To Rekkene als wel goodnessewel her goodnessewel her goodnesse as beautee
Neuyr was such an othir as is shee
I pray god in honour hir susteene
I wold she were of al Europe queene
¶ In hir is hye beaute withoutyn pride
Thought without grenehod of foly
To alle hir werkys vertu is his guyde
HumblenesseMiknesHumblenesseMiknes hath slayn in hir al tyranny
She is myrrouris veray myrrouris veray myrrour of al curtasy

¶ Al this voice was sooth as god is trewe
But now to ꝓproposeto age ꝓproposeto age ꝓpropose lat vs turne agayn

¶ Among othir thinges specially
Þise mchauntz had told þe souldan of dam CustāmceCustāmcedam Custāmce
So gret noblesse in ernest ceriously
Þat þis souldan hath caught so gret pleasaıı̄unce

AndþᵗatAnd þᵗat al his lust and al his besy cure
Was to loue hir whils his lyfe may endure
¶ Par auenture in thilk large book
Which is clepid heuyn wretyn was
ThatWithThatWith sterres whan that he his birthe took
That he for loue shuld haue be ded allas
For in the sterres clerer þan is the glas
Ys wretyn who so couth yt rede
The deth of euery man withoutyn drede
¶ In histories many wynters beforn
Was wretyn the deth of Ector ⁊and achilles
Of pompe of Iulius or thei were born
The strife of thebes and of hercules
And sampson tyrus ⁊and of socrates
But mennys wytte been so dulle
That no wight can rede yt at the fulle
¶ This souldan for his pryue counsel sent
And shortly of this mater for to pace
He has declared to thaym his entent
And seid hem certayn but yif he myght haue
To haue Custaunce within a litil space
He ne was but ded he charged hem in hye
To shapyn for his deth som remedye
¶ Dyuerse men dyuersez thingez sayden
Thei argumentis castyn vp and doun
Many a subtyle reson forth þei layden
Thei speke of magik and of abusyon
But fully as in conclusion
Thei kan not seen in þᵗatin þᵗat non avauntage
Ne in non othir wey sauf mariage
¶ Than saugh þei therin such difficultee
But wey of Reson to spoke al playn
By cause that ther was such adủer/resytee
Betwen þair bothe two lawys þat þei sayn
That trowtrow no cristen prince wold fayn
Weddyn hys child vnder oᵘur lawys vn seete
That vs were taught by mahoun oᵘur ꝓpropheete
¶ And he answerd rather þan I shuld lese
Custaunce ; I cristenyd wil be doutles
I mot be hirs I may no othir cheese
I pᵃy yow be with yoᵘur argumentis in pees
Sauyth my lyfe and beeth not rekkelees
To gete hir that hath my lyfe in cure
For in this wo I may no leng endure
¶ What nedith gretter dilatacion ;
By trety and ambariatrye
And by þeþe popis mediacyon
And alle the chirches and al the cheualrye
That in destruccyon of Maumeutrye
And encrees of cristes lawe dere
Thei been accordid so as yee shal aft̉er/reaft̉er/re heere
¶ How that the souldan and his baronage
And also his leegis shul cristynd be
And he shal haue Custaunce in mariage
And certayn gold I ne wot what quantite
And herto foundyn sufficiaunt seurte
This same accord was sworn on outhir syde
Now fayre Custaunce almyghty god þᵉ gi
¶ Now wold sum man wayten as I gesse
That I shuld telltell alle the purueaunce
That the emperour of his gret noblesse
Hath shapyn for his doughtyr dam Custaıı̄unce
Wel may men knowen þat sogret ordinaıı̄unce
May no man telle in asoaso lytel inin a lytellytel clause
As was arayed for so hye a cause
¶ Bisshoppis ben shapyn wᵗith hir to weende
Lordys ladyes knyghtys of Renoun
And othir folk ynowe this is the eende
And notified is thurghout all the toun
That eủer/rey wight with good deuocyoun
Shuld pray criste that hehe this mariage
Receyue in gree and speede the viage
¶ The day is comyn of hir departyng
I sey the woful day fatalfatal is come
That ther may be no lenger tareyng
But forthward þei hem dresse al ⁊and some
Custaunce that with sorwe was oủer/recome
Ful pale arisith and dressith hir to weende
For wel she seeth ther is non othir eende
¶ Allas what wondir is þough she weeped
That shal be send to straunge nacyon
Fro frendis that so tendirly hir keepid
And to be boundyn vndir subieccyon
Of one she knowith notnot his condicyon
Husbandys been good and þᵗat is knowe ful yore
And that knowyn wyfes I dar say ȝowȝow no more
¶ Fadir she said thi woful child Custaunce
Thi yong doughtyr fostrid vp so soft
And yee my modir my souerayn pleasaıı̄unce
Ouer alle thing out takyn crist on loft
Custaunce your doughtir hir recomāmudeþ oft
Vnto yoᵘur grace for I shal vn to surrey
Ne shal I neuer more seen yow with eye
¶ Allas vn to the barbary nacyon
I most anon sithen yt is your wille
ByButteByButte criste that steruyd for oᵘur redempcyon
So gif me grace his hestis to fulfille
I wrecchid womman no force þough I spille
Wymmen ben born to thraldom ⁊and penaunce
And to been vndir mannys goủer/renaunce
¶ I trowe þat troy whan pʳrus brak þᵉ wal
Of ylion that brent thebes the cyte
Ne Rome for þe harme þurgh hanibal
That Romayns has venquysshid tymes thre
Ne haswashaswas herd such a wepyng for pytee
As in the chambyr for hir departyng
But forth she mot wheythir she wepe or syng
¶ O furst moeuyng cruel firmament
With thi diournal swowgh þat crowdith ay
And hurlest from the est vn to the occident
That naturally wold hold an othir way
Thi crowdyng settys the heuyn in such aray
At the begynnyng of the furst viage
That cruel mars hath slayn that mariage
¶ Infortunate ascendent tortuose
Of which the lord is helples allas
Out of this angle in to his hous
Of mars o attatazir as in this caas
Thou not wyckyd to enbraas
Thou knyttest thethe there thou art not receyuyd
There thou were wel from yt art þou weyuyd
¶ O imprudent emperour of Rome allas
Was ther no philosophre in al thi toun
As no tyme is bettyr than oþ̉er/re in such caas
Of viage is ther non eleccyoun
Namly to folk of high condicyoun
Nat whan a roote is of a bussh y knowe
Allas we be to lewde or to slowe
¶ To shippe is brought this woful faire mayde
Solempnly with euery circumstaunce
Now ihu criste be with yow alle she sayde
There is no more but fare wel fayre custaıı̄unce
She peynyth hir to make good contynaunce
And forth I lat hir sayle in this manere
And toᵘrne I wil agayn to my matere
¶ The modyr of the souldan welle of vices
Espied hath hir sonys playn entent
How he wil lete his owne sacrifices
And right anon she for hir counsel sent
And thei be comyn to know hir entent
And whan assemblid was that folk in feere
She sette hir doun and said as yee shal heere
¶ Lordys quoth she yee knowe wel eủer/reychon
How þᵗatþᵗat my sone is in poynt for to leete
The holy lawes of oure alkaron
Youyn by goddis messager macomeete
But on avow to grete god I heete
The lyfe rather out of my body sterte
Than macometys lawe out of my herte
¶ What shal vs betyde of this newe lawe
But thraldome to oure body in penaunce
And aftyrward in helle to be drawe
For we renyed mahoun oure creaunce
But lordys wil yee make assuraunce
As I shal say assentyng to my lore
And I shal make vs sauff for euermore
¶ Thei swoore and assentyd eủer/reychon
To lyuen with hir and dye and by hir stande
And eủer/rey wight in the best wyse he can
To strengthe hir shal his frendis fande
And she hath this empryse takyn on hande
Which yee shal here aftir hir deuyse
And to hem alle she spak on this wyse
¶ We shul vs feyn cristendom to take
Cold watyr shal greue vs but a lyte
And I shal such a fest and Reuel make
That as I trowe I shal the souldan quyte
For though his wyfe be cristenyd neủer/re so white
Shal she haue nede to wassh away þe rede
Þough she a fount ful of wat̉er/re wᵗith hir lede
¶ O souldanesse Roote of iniquyte
O virago thou semira the secunde
O serpent vndir femynyte
Like to the serpent deep in helle bounde
O fayned womman al that may confounde
Vertu and Innocency thurgh thi malice
Is bredde in thi breest of euer ilk a vice
¶ O sathan enuyous sithen thilk day
That thou were chasid from oure heritage
Wel knowist thou of wymmen þe old way
Thou madest eue bryng vs in seruage
Thou wil for doon this cristen mariage
Thyn Instrumentys so welaway the while
Makys thou of wymmen whan þᵘ wil beguyle
¶ This souldanesse whom I thus blame ⁊and wary
Leet pryuely hir counsel gon his way
What shuld I on this tale lenger tarye
She rydes to the souldan on a day
And said hym she wold Receyue his lay
And cristendom of preestes hand fong
Repentyng hir she hethen was so long
¶ Besechyng hym to do hir þat honour
That she myght haue the cristēm folk to fest
To please hem I wold do my labour
The souldan said I wil do at your hest
And knelyng thankid hir of þat request
So glad he was he ne wist what to say
She kissid hir sone and home she gos hir way
¶ Arryued been thise cristen folk to lande
In surrey with a gret solempn route
And hastily this souldan sent his sonde
Furst to his modir and al þe Reigne aboute
And said his wyfe was comyn out of doute
And praid þᵗatþᵗat to popelpopel ryde agayn the queen
The honour of his Regne for to susteen
¶ Gret was the prees and ryche was þᵉ aray
Of surreyns and Romayns mette in feere
The moder of the souldan ryche and gay
Receyuyd hir with als glad a cheere
As any moder myght hir doughtir deere
And to the next cytee there beside
A softe paas solemply thei ryde
¶ Nought trowe I the tryumphe of Iulius
Of which that lucan makis suych a bost
Was Royaller ne more curyous
Þan was the assemblee of that blissid host
But this scorpion this wykkid gost
The souldanesse for al hir flateryng
Cast vndir this ful mortally to styng
¶ The souldan comys hym self sone aftir this
So Royally that wonder is to telle
He welcomyth hir with ioy and blisse
And thus in myrtheand ioy I lete hem duelle
The frute of this mater is þat I telle
When tyme come men thought yt for þe best
That Reuel styntyd and men gon to her rest
¶ The tyme come this old souldanesse
Ordeyned hath the fest which I told
And to this fest cristen folk hem dresse
In general bothe yong and old
Here may men feste and royalte behold
And dayntes mo than I can deuyse
But al to deere thai bought yt ar thei ryse
¶ O sodeyn wo that euyr art successour
To worldly blisse spreynt with bytternesse
The eende of the ioye of oure worldly labour
Wo occupyeth the fyne of oure gladnesse
Herkene this councel for thi sykernesse
Vppon thi glad day haue thou in mynde
The vnwar wo or harme that comyth behynde
¶ For soothly for to telle at a wurd
The souldan and the cristen eủer/reychon
Been al to hewe and stykyd at the bord
But yif yt were only damedame Custaıı̄unce allon
This old souldanesse cursid cron
Has with hir freendis doon þis cursid dede
For she hir self wold al the cuntre lede
¶ Ne ther ne was surreyn nonnon þᵗat was conủer/retyd
That of the councel of the souldan wot
That he ne was alto hewe or he astertyd
And Custaıı̄unce took thei anon ful hot
And in a shippe al steerles god yt wot
Thei haue hir sette and bid hir lern to sayle
Out of surrey agayn in to ytaile
