¶ The senatours wyfe hir aunte was
But for al that she knew hir neuer þe more
I wil no lenger tarye in this caas
But to kyng allaf of qwhich I spak yore
That for his wyfe wepith and sighith sore
I wil returne and lete I wil Custaunce
Vnder the goudegoude senatouris gouernaunce
¶ Kyng allaf which þat his modir had slayn
Vppon a day fel in such Repentaunce
That yif I shortly shal telle and playn
To Rome he comyth to Receyue penaunce
And putte hym vndir the popis ordinaıı̄unce
In high and lowe and Ihıı̄un crist besought
To forgif hym his wikkid werkis þᵗat he had wrought
¶ The fame a non thurghout Rome is born
How allaf kyng shuld come in pilgrymage
By herberiours that went hym beforn
For which the senatoure as was vsage
Rode hym agayn ⁊and mony of his lynage
As wel to see his high magnificence
As for to do any kyng Reuerence
¶ Gret cheere dooth this noble senatoure
To kyng allaf and he to hym also
Euerich of hem did othir gret honour
And so befel that in a day or two
This senatour is to kyng allaf go
To fest and yif I shal not lye
Custauncis sone goth in his companye
¶ Sum men wold sey at the Request of custaıı̄unce
This senatour ladde this child to the feste
I may not telle euery circumstaunce
Be as be may there was he at the lest
Bot sooth is this ; not at his modir hest
Before kyng allaf duryng the mete space
The child stood lokyng in the kynges face
¶ This allaf kyng had of þis child gret wondir
And to the senatour he seid anon
Whoos is the child that stondis yonder
I ne wot quoth he by god and by seynt Iohn
A modir he hath but fadir has he non
That I of wot and shortly in a stounde
He told allaf how that this child was founde
¶ But god wot quoth this senatoᵘur also
So vertuous a lyuer in al my lyfe
Ne saugh I neủer/re ; ne herd of suych no mo
Of worldly wommen of mayden ne of wyfe
I dar wel sey that she hadde leuer a knyfe
Went thurgh hir breest þen been a woman wikke
Ther is no man couth bring hir to þe prikke
¶ Now was this child as like to Custaunce
As possible is a creature to be
This allaf hath this face in Remembraıı̄unce
Ofdam Custaunce and theron musid be
Yif that þe childis modir were ought she
That is his wyfe and pryuely he sight
And of his contenaunce he was no þing light
¶ But par fay thought he fantasme is in my hed
I ought to deme of skilful Iuggement
That in the salt see my wyfe is ded
And aftirward he made his argument
What yif crist haue hir hider sent
My wife by see als wel as he hir sent hom
To my cuntre ; fro theyns as she cam from
¶ And aftir noone home with þe senatoure
For to see this wondir chaunce
The senatoure dooth allaf gret honour
And hastily he send aftir Custaunce
But trustith wel hyr lust not to daunce
Whan she wist wherfore was that sonde
Vnnethe vppon hir feet myght she stonde
¶ Whan allaf saugh his wyfe fayre he hir grette
And wept yt is ruthe for to see
For at the fustfurstfurst look he on hir sette
He knew verraly that yt was she
And for sorwe dombe she stood as a tree
So was hir hert in such distresse
Whan she Remembrid his vnkyndnesse
¶ Thryes she swounyd in his owne sight
He wept and hym excused pitously
Now god quoth he and alle halwys bright
So wistly on my soule haue mcy
That of youre harme as giltles am I
As is Maurice my sone like thi face
Ellis the fende me fecche out of this place
¶ Longe was the sorwyng ⁊and þe byttir payne
Er thei here woful hertys myght asseese
Gret was the pite for to here hem playne
Thurgh which playntes began þeir sorwe encrese
I pray yow allfallallf my sorwe to relese
I may not telle hir wo til to morwe
I so sory am to speke of hir sorwe
¶ But fynally whan the sooth is wist
That allaf giltles was of hir wo
I trowe an hundreth tymes thei kist
And such a blisse is betwix them two
But sauf the ioy that lastys euermo
There is non like that any creature
Hath seen or shal see whils þe world may endure
¶ Than prayed she hir husband mekely
In releef of hir pitous long peyne
That he wold pray hir fadirþe emperourhir fadirþe emperour especially
That of his maieste he wold enclyne
To vouchsauff som day with hym to dyne
She preyeth eke þat he wold by no weye
Vnto hir fadir no wurde of yt seye
¶ Sum men wold sey that the child maurice
Dooth this message vnto the Emperour
But as I gesse allaf was not so nyse
To hym that was so soueraigne of honour
As he that is of cristen folk the flour
To send any child but yt is best to deme
That he went hym self and so yt may lest sem
¶ This Emperour hath grauntid gentilly
To come to dyne as he hym besought
And with redy eye he lookid besily
Vppon this child and on his modir thought
Allaf goth to his In as hym ought
And arrayed for this fest on euery wise
As ferforth as his kunnyng may suffise
¶ The morwe cam and allaf gan hym dresse
And eke his wife this Emperour for to mete
And forth thei ryden in ioy and in gladnesse
And whan she saugh hir fadir in the strete
She lyghtith doun and fallith to his feete
Fadir qd she your yong child Custaunce
Is now ful clene out of yoᵘur Remembraunce
¶ I am your doughtir Custaunce qd she
That whilom yee sent vnto surry
It am I fadir that inin the salt see
Was put allone and dampnyd for to dye
Now good fadir mercy I yow crye
Send me no more vn to hethenesse
But thanke hierhier my lord of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pitous ioy tellyn al
Betwix hem sithen thei been thus mette
But of my tale make an ende I shal
The day goth fast I wil no lenger lette
Thise gladde folk to dyner þei hem sette
With ioy and blisse I lete hem at mete dwelle
A Ml folk wel mo than I can telle
¶ The child maurice was sithen emperour
Made by the Pope and lyued cristenly
To cristes chirche did he gret honour
But lat al his history passe by
Of Custaunce is my tale especially
In olde Romayn gestis men may fynde
Maurice lyfe ; for I bere yt not in mynde
¶ This kyng allaf when he his tyme sy
With Custaunce his holy wife so sweete
To England þei come the right wey
Where as thei lyue in Ioy and in quyete
But litil while yt lastis I yow beheete
Ioy of this world for tyme wil not abyde
From day to day yt chaungith as þe tide
Who lyueth euer in such delyte on day
That ne moeuyd is outhir conscience
Or Ire or talent or sum kyns affray
Envye or pryde or passion or offence
I sey but for this ende and this sentence
That lytel while in ioy andin plesaıı̄unce
Lastith the blisse of allaf and Custaıı̄unce
¶ For deth that takith of hygh ⁊and lowe his rent
Not passid fully a yeer as I gesse
Out of this world kyng allaf he hent
For that Custaunce hath gret heuynesse
Now lat vs prey god his soule blisse
And dam Custaunce finally to say
Toward þe town of Rome she goth hir way
¶ To Rome is comyn this holy creature
And fyndith hir freendis hool ⁊and sounde
Now is she skapid al hir aduenture
And whan she had hir fadir founde
Doun on hir knees fallith she to grounde
Wepyng for tendirnesse in hert blithe
She thankith god a hundrith Ml sithe
¶ In vertu and in almesse dede
They lyuen alle and neuer on sundir went
Til deth departe hem þis lyfe þei leede
And farith now wel my tale is at an end
Now Ihu crist þat of his myght may send
Ioy aftir wo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle þat been in this place

Explicit fabula sermentis ad ⁊andlb: legem sine speritu et iam incipit ⁊andlb: prologus fabule Clerici Oxome
Syr clerk of Oxenford oure host saide
Ye ryde ale coy ⁊and stille as dooþ a mayde
Were new spousid sittyng at þe bord
This day ne herd I of yoᵘur tunge a wurd
I trow yee study about som sophisme
And Sulamon saith euery thyng hath tyme
For goddis loue as beeth of bettir chere
Yt is no tyme to study here
Telle vs sum mery tale by your fay
For what man þat is entrid in to play
Hym nedis most vn to the play assent
But preche not a freres doon in lent
To make vs for oure old synnes wepe
Ne that your tale make vs for to sleepe
Telle vs mery tidynges of aduenturys
Your termes your colours and your figures
Kepe ye in store til yee endite
Hygh stile as whan þat men to kyngys wryte
Spekyth so playn at this tyme I yow preye
That we may vndirstonde what yee say
This wurthi clerk benygnely answerde
Host qd he I am vndir your yerde
Yee haue of vs alle now þe gouernaunce
And therfore wil I do yow obeisaunce
Ale fewe as reson askith hardily
I wil yow telle a tale which that I
Lerd at padaw of a wurthi clerk
Prouyd by his wordis and his werk
He is now ded and naylid in a chest
I pray god gyf his soule good rest
Ffrauncys petrak the laurirce poete
Hight this clerk whos rethoryk sweet
Enlumyned al ytaly of poetrye
As lynyan did of philosophie
Or lawe or othir ⁊andabsent:arte particuler
But deth that wil not suffre vs duelle heer
But as yt were a twııklyng of an eye
Them bothe hath slawe and alle shal we dye
Forthermore of to telle of Þis wurthi man
That taught me Þis tale as I bigan
I seye that first with his style he enditith
Er he the body of his tale writeth
A prohem in which discrnyth he
Pymonnd and of salucis the cuntre
And spekes of app the hilles hye
That been the boundys of westlumbardye
And of the mount vesulus in especial
Where as the poo out of a welle smal
Taketh his furste spryngyng and his coᵘurs
By ꝒProresse of tyme and of hours
To Emeleward to ferare and venyce
The whiche a long thing were to deuyse
And trewly as to my Iuggement
Me thynketh yt athyng impertinent
Sauf that he wil comoyne his matere
But this is the tale which Þᵗat yee shal here
Explicit prohemium fabule Cle⁊andlb: ria Oxome. ⁊and incipit fabula eiusdem
There is at the right side of ytayle
Doun at the rote of vesulus Þe colde
A lusty playn habundaunte of vitayle
Where many⁊andabsent:many a toure and toun Þow may bebeholde
That foundid were in tyme of fadris olde
And many an othir delectable sight
And salus this noble cuntre hight
¶ A Xarkys whilom lord of that land
As his wurthi eldres were hym before
And obeisaunt and redy to his hand
Were alle his leegis bothe lesse and more
Thus in delyt he lyueth and hath don yore
Belouyd and dred by fauour and fortune
Bothe of his lordis and of his comune
Therwith he was to speke as of linage
The gentlest born of lumbardye
A fair ꝐPer/Parsone and strong ⁊and yong of age
And ful of honoure and of curtesye
Discrete ynogh his contre to guye
Sauf in sum thinges Þat he was to blame
And walter was this yonge lordes name
¶ I blame hym thus that he considred nought
In tyme comyng what myghte betyde
But on his lust psent was al his thought
And for to hauke and hunte on euery side
That welnygh alle othire cures he let slide
And he ne wold and that was werst of alle
Wedde no wyfe for ought Þat may bifalle
¶ Only that poynt his poeple bare so sore
Þat flokmele on a day to hym thei went
And of hem one of Þe wisest Þᵗat was of lore
Or ellis that Þe lord wold best assente
That he shulde telle hym what his poeple ment
Or ellis couth he shewe wel his matere
He to the markys seid as yee shal heere
O noble Markys your humanitee
Assurith vs and geuyth vs hardynesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to yow may shewe oure heuynesse
Acceptith lord now of yoᵘur gentillesse
That we with pytous hert to yow pleyn
And lete your erys my voice not disdeyn
¶ Al Þough I haue not doo in this matere
More Þan an othir man hauys in this place
Yit for als mych as yee my lord so deere
Haue alway shewid me favoᵘur and grace
I dar the bettir haue of yow a space
Of audience to shewyn oure requeste
And yee my lord to do right as yow lyst
¶ For certis lord so wel vs likith yow
And al youre werk and euer haue doon Þᵗat we
Ne couth deuyse oure self how
That we myghte lyue in more felicite
Sauf one thyng lord yif yoᵘur wil be
That for to be a weddid man yow lyst
Than were youryour poeple in soueraigne hertis rest
¶ Bowith yoᵘur necke vndir that blisseful yok
Of souereignete and not of seruice
Whiche that men clepe spousayl or wedlok
And thynk lord uppon yoᵘur werkys wyse
b. For Þough we sleepe wake or renne or ryde
a. How that oure dayes passe in sundry wyse
Ay neighith Þe tyme yt wil no man abyde
¶ And Þough yoᵘur grene yougÞe floure as yitte
In crepith age alway als stille as ston
And deth manassheth euer age and smytte
In ich estate for there eskapith non
That also certayn as we knowe ichon
That we shal dye. as as vncerteyn we alle
Ben of that day whan deth shal on vs falle

div.l: ¶ Acceptith than of vs oure trew entent
That yit neuyr refusid your hest
And wil lord yif yee wil assent
Chese yow a wyfe in short tyme at Þe lest
Borne of the gentillest and of Þe mest
Of al this land and so yt oughte to seme
Honour to god and yow as yee can deme
¶Delyuere vs out of alle Þe besy drede
And taketh a wyfe for hye goddis sake
For yif yt be fel as god forbede
That thurgh your deth your lynage shulde s
And that a strong successour shulde tak
Youre heritage. o wo were vs on lyfe
Wherfore we pray yow hastily to wyfe
Here meke prayere and here meke cheere
Made the markys to haue pytee
I wil quoth he myn owne poeple deere
To Þat I neuer I thought erst constrayn me
I me roioysed in my libertee
That seldom tyme is foundyn in mariage
Ther I was free I mot be in seruage
¶ But never the lesse I se your trew entente
And trust vppon your witte and haue don ay
Wherfore of my fre wyl I wil assent
To wedde me as sone as I may
But there as yee haue ꝓprofrid to day
To chese me a wyf I wil relese
That choys ⁊and I pray yow of Þat profre sese
¶ For god wot that childern ofte tyme been
Vnlyke hir wurthi eldere hem before
Bounte comyth of god and not of the streen
I truste in good bounte and therfore
to Jhu criste that god is euermore
My mariage and myn eastate and rest
I hym betake he may do as hym lyst
¶ Lat me allone in fechyng of my wyfe
That charge vppon my bak I wil endure
But I yow pray and charge yow vppon yoᵘur lyf
That whom so I take yee me ensure
To wurshippe his while that hir lyfe may endure
In word and werk boÞe here and ellis where
As she an emperours doughtyr were
¶And forthermore this shal yee swere Þat yee
Ageyn my choyce shal neuer grucche ne stryfe
For sythen I shal forgo my liberte
At your Requeste as euere mot I thryfe
Ther as my hert is set ther wil I wyfe
And but yee wil assentyn in this manere
I pray yow speke no more of this matere
¶ With hertly wil they sworen and assentyn
To al this thing Þer said no wight nay
Bisetyng hym of grace or that Þei wentyn
That he wold vouchesauf to sette a day
Of his spousaile as sone as euer he may
For yit alwey the poeple sum dele dredde
Lest that the markys no wyfe wold wedde
¶He grauntyd hem a day such as hym lyst
On whilk he wold be weddid sikerly
And said he did al this at here Requeste
And thei with humble entent buxumly
Knelyng on here knees ful Reuerently
Hym thankyn alle and thus haue an ende
Of here entent and hom agayn weende
¶And thervppon he to his officers
Comaundith for the feste to purvey
And to his pryuee knyghtis and esquyers
Such charges hem gaf as hym list on hem ley
And thai to his comaundement do obey
And euerich of hem dooth al diligence
To doon vn to the feste Reuerence
¶Not fer fro thilk paleys honourable
Where as the markys shoop his mariage
Ther stood a thorp in sight ful delectable
In which that pouer folk of Þat village
Haddyn her bestis and here heribage
And of here labour took here sustenaunce
Aftir that the erthe gaf hem habundaunce
¶Among thise pouer folk Þ̉er/re duellyd a man
Which that was hold Þe pouerest of hem alle
But hygh god sum tyme send can
His grace in to a litil oxes stalle
Ianicla men of that thorp hym calle
A doughtir he hadde fayre ynough in sighte
And Grysilde this yong mayden hight
¶But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she one the fayreste vnder sonne
Ful pouerly fostred was she
No likerous lust was in hir hert ronne
Wel ofter of the welle Þan of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu please
She knew wel labour but no thing ease
¶But Þough Þis mayde tendre were of age
Yit in here brest of hir virginitee
Ther was enclosid rype and sad curage
And in gret Reuerence and charyte
Hire old fader t fostred she
A fewe sheep on Þe feld she spynnyng on kept
She wold not be ydel vnto she slept
¶And when she homward came she wold bryng
Wurtys and othir herbis tymes oft
Vnto hir old fadres sustenyng
And ay tendirly she kept his lyfe on loft
With honest kepyng benyngly and soft
And with al maner obeisaunce and ofandof diligence
That child may doo to faders Reuence
¶Vppon Grisilde that pouer creature
Ful ofte tymes Þ̉er/re markes set his eye
As he on huntyng rode par auenture
And whan yt befal he myght hir espye
He mot with wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen cast on hir but in sad wyse
Vppon hir chere he wold hym ofte aduyse
¶Couetyng in his hert hir wommanhede
And eke hir vertues passyng euery wight
Of so yong age als wel in chere as dede
For thogh poeple hath non insight
In vertu he considred right
Hir bounte and that dispose he wold
To wedde hir only yif he wedden shuld
¶The day of weddyng came but no wight can
Telle what womman yt shuld be
For which thing wondir many a man
And said whan thei were in pryuete
Wil not oure lord leue his vanyte
Wil he not wedde allas allas Þe while
Whi wil he hym self and vs beguyle
¶But neuer the lesse the markys hath do make
Of gemmys set in gold and in asure
Brochis and Rynges for Grisildes sake
And of the clothing took meusure
Of a mayden like to hir stature
And eek of othir ournamentis alle
That vnto such aweddyng shal falle
¶The tyme of vnderne Þe same day
Approchith Þat this weddyng shuld be
And al the place put was in array
Bothe halle and chambris ech in his degree
Houseis of offices stuffid with plentee
Ther mayst thou see of daynteuous vitayl
That may be founde als ferre as lastis ytail
¶This royal markys richely arrayed
With lordis and ladies in his company
The whith that to the fest were prayed
And of his retenu the bachillery
With many soun of diverse melody
Vnto the village of the which I tolde
In this array the righte way thei hold
¶Grisild of this god wot wel Innocent
That for hir shapyn was al this array
To fecche watir at a welle is went
And comyth ageyn as sone as eủer/re she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd Þat ilke day
The Markys sholde wedde and if she myghte
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte
thatÞethatÞe markis shuld wedde and yif she myght
She wold fayn haue seen of Þat sight
¶She thoght she wold with othir maydenys sto
That been my felawys and in oure dore see
The markis wyfe and Þerfore wil I fond
To don at home als sone as yt may bee
The laboure the which Þat longeth vn to me
And than I may at leyser hir behold
Yif she thisththis way vnto the castel hold
¶And als she wold ouer hir thresshold gon
The markis cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir watir pot a non
Byside the thresshold of the oxen stalle
And doun vppon hir knees she gan to falle
And with Þat contynaunce knelid stille
Til she had herd what was the lordis wille
¶This thoghtful markis spak vnto Þe mayde
Ful soborly and said in this manere
Where is youyouyour fader o grisild he saide
And she with Reuerence and humble cheere
Answerd lord he is al redy heere
And in she gooth without legger lette
And to the markis she hir fadir fette.
¶He by the hand took this old man
And thus seid whan he had hym a syde
Ianicula I neuer may ne can
Lenger the pleasaunce of myn hert hyde
Yif that thou vouchesauf what so betyde
Thi doughtir wil I take er that I weende
As to my wyfe to oure lyfes eende
¶Thou louys me I wot yt wel certayn
And art my faithful legeman ybore
And al that likes me I dar wel sayn
Yt likith the and especially therfore
Telle me that poynt as I haue said before
Yif that thou wil vn to my purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in lawe
This subitan caas this man astonyed so
Þat red he wex abasshid al ⁊and quakyng
He stood; vnnethis said he wurdis mo
But only this; lord qd he my willyng
Is as yee wil; ne ageyn youre likyng
I wil no thyng do; yee be my lord so deere
aght as yow list gouernyth this matere
¶Yet wil I do this quoth Þe markis softly
That in a chambre I and thou and she
Haue a collacyon and wotyst thou whi
For I wil aske if yit hir wille be
To be my wyfe and rule hir aftir me
And al this shal be doon in thi presence
I wil not speke out of thyn audience
¶And in the chambir while Þei were aboute
Here trety which yee shul aftir heere
The poeple cam vn to the hous withoute
And wondird hem in how honest manere
And daynteffully she kept hir fadir deere
But uttirly Grysild wondir myght
For neuer eÞft saugh she suych a sight
¶No wondir is yif she were astoonyd
To see so gret a gest come in that place
She neuer was to such gestis wonyd
For which she lokid with a ful pale face
But forth this mater shortly for to chace
Thise been the wurdes that this markis said
To this benyngne and stedfast mayd
Grisild he seid yee wil wel vndirstand
Yt likith to your fadir and to me
That I yow wedde and eke yt may so stand
As I suppose that yee wil Þat yt so bee
But this demaunde aske I furst qd he
That sithen yt shal be don in hasty wyse
Wil yee assent or ellis yow aduyse
¶I say this be yee redy with good herte
To al my lust and I frely may
As yow best thenke; doo ye laugh or smerte
And neuer to grucche nyght ne day
And eke whan I sey yee; sey yee not nay.
Nouthir by wurd ne by froward contynnace
Swere ⁊andabsent: this; and I sure yow alliannce
¶Wrondryng vppon this wurd quakyng for drede
She said lord vndigne and vnwurthi
Am I to thilk honour that yee me beede
But as yee wil your self so wil I
And here I swere that neuer willingly
In werk ne thoght I nyl yow disobeye
For to be /⁊andabsent:/ dede Þough me were loth to deye
¶This is ynough Gresild deere qd he
And forth he goth with a noble cheere
Out at the doore and aftyr cam she
And to the poeple he said on this manere

Uepyng and waylyng care ⁊and othir sorwe
I knowe ynough on euyn ⁊and on morwe
Quoth this merchaunt and so dooth othir mo
That weddid been I trowe that yt be so
For wel I wot yt farys so with me
I haue a wyfe the werst that may be
For though the feend to hir couplid were
She wold hym ouer macche I dar wel swere
What shuld yow reherce in especial
Hir hygh malice a shrew she is at al
Ther is a long and a large difference
Betwix Grisildis gret pacience
And of my wyfe the passyng cruelte
Were I vnboundyn also mot I the
I wold neuer aftir come in the snare
We weddid men lyuyn in sorwe and care
Assay who so wil and he shal yt fynde
That I say sooth by seynt thomas of ynde
As for the more part I sey not alle
God sheld that yt shuld so befalle
O good syr ost I haue weddid be
This monethis two and more not parde
And yit trow I that he that al his lyfe
Hath weddid be ; though þᵗat men wold hym ryse
Telle so myche sorwe as I now heere
Couth telle of wyfes cursidnesse
Now quoth oure host merchaunt so god yow blisse
Sithen yee so mekil knowyn of that art
Ful hertily I pray yow telle vs sum part
Gladly qd he but of myne owne sore
For sory hert I may telle no more

Uhilom ther was duellyng in lumbardy
A wurthi knyght that was of Pauy
In which he lyuyd in gret prosperytee
And sixti yeere a wyfles man was he
And folwid alway his bodily delyte
On wommen ther was his appetite
As doon thise foolis that been seculeer
And whan he was passid sixti yeer
Were yt for holynesse or for dotage
I can not sey ; but such a gret curage
Hadde this knyght to been a weddid man
That day and nyght he dooth al þat he can
To aspye where that he myght weddid be
Prayng oure lord to graunt hym that he
Myght onys knowe that blisseful lyfe
That is betwix an husbond and his wyfe
And for to lyue vndir that holy bonde
The whiche god furst god man to womman bond
Non othir lyfe seid he is wurth a bene
For weddelok is so easy and so clene
That in this world yt is a paradise
Thus seid this old knyght that was so wyse
And sooth yt is as god is kyng kyngto take
To take a wyfe yt is a glorious thing
And namely whan a man is old and hore
Than is a wyfe the frute of his tresore
Than shuld he take hym a yong wyfe ⁊and a fayre
On which he myght engendre hym an heyre
And lede his lyfe in ioye and in solace
Where as thise bachilers syng allas
Whan that the fynde any aduersite
In loue whiche is but childis vanyte
And truly yt sittith wel to be so
That bachillers oftyn haue payne and wo
On brotel grounde thei beldyn brytelnesse
Thei fyndyn falshed whan that þei wene sikirnesse
Thei lyue but as a brid or as a beste
In liberte and vndir non areste
There as a weddid man in his eastate
Ledeth his lyfe blissefully and ordinatte
Vndir the yokke of maryage ybounde
Wel may herte in ioy and blisse habounde
For who can be so buxum as a wyfe ;
Who is so trewe and eke so attentyfe ;
To kepe hym seeke and hool as his make ;
For wel ne wo she wol not hym forsake .
She nys not wery hym to loue and serue
Þough þat he ligge bedred til he sterue .
And yit sōmmme clerkis seyn yt is not so
Of which theofrast is one of tho
What rek þough theofrast lyst to lye .
Ne take no wyfe qd he for husbondrye
And for to spare in houshold thi dispence
A trewe seruaunt doth more diligence
Thi good to kepe than thyn owne wyfe
For she wil cleyme half part in her lyfe
And yif thou be seeke als god me saue
Quoth he thi frendis or a trewe knaue
Wil kepe the bettir þan she þat waytith ay
Aftir thi good and hath doon many a day
And yif thou take a wyfe be wel war
Of a peril which declare I ne dar
This entent and an hundrith sithis wurs
Writys this man ther god hym self curs
But take no keep of such vanytee
Diffye theofrast and herkyn me
A wyfe is goddis gyft verraly
Al maner othir gyftys hardily
As londis rentys pasturis or comune
Or othir moruable goodis ben giftes of fortune
That passyn as thi shadowe of a wal
But dredith yif pleynly speke I shal
A wyfe wil laste and in thy house endure
Wel lenger þan the lust þat aduenture
Mariage is a ful gret sacrament
Who so hath no wyfe I hold hym but shent
He lyues helples and al desolate .
I speke of folk in seculer estate
And herkyn whi I say not this for nought
The womman is for mannys help wrought
The high god whan he had adam makid
And saw hym a non holy nakid
God of his gret goodnesse seid thanne
Lat vs now make an help to this manne
Like to hym self and than he made eue
Here may yee see and here may yee preue
That wyfe is mannys help and his comfort
His paradise terrestre and his disport
So buxum and so vertuous is she
Than must vs nedys lyfe in vnitee
One flessh thei been ; and one flessh as I gesse
Hath but one werk in welthe and in distresse
A wyfe a seynt mary benedicite
How myght a man haue any aduersitee
That hath a wyfe certys I can not say
The blisse that is betwyx hem tway
There may no tounge telle or hert thinke
Yif he be pouer she helpith hym to swynke
She keepith his good and wastis neủer/re adeel
And al that hir husbond lyst hir likith weel
She says not onys nay whan he says yee
Dooth this seith he al redy sir saith she
O blisseful ordre O Wedlok precyous
Thou art so mery and eke so vertuous
And so commendid and apreuyd eke
That euery man that holdith hym wurth a aleek
Vppon his bare knees ought al his lyfe
To thankyn god thath hath sent hym a wyfe
Outhir to pray to god hym for to sende
A wyfe to last hym to his lyfis ende
For than his lyfe is sette in sikernesse
He may not be deceyuyd as I gesse
So that he wirke aftir his wyfes red
Than may he boldly hold vp his hed
Thei been so trewe and eke so wyse
For which yif thou wil wirke as the wyse
Do alway so as wymmen wil the rede
Lo how that Iacob as thise clerkis rede
By good counsel of his modir Rebekke
Bond the kyddis skyn aboute his nekke
For the which his fadirs benisou he wan
Lo eke Iudith as the history telle can
By wise councel she poeple kept
And slough hym Olopherne whils he slept
Lo abigael by good councel how she
Sauyd hir husbond Nabal whan þat she
Shuld haue been slayn ; and looke astir also
By good councel delyuerid out of wo
The poeple of god and made hym
Of aȝure enhauncyd for to been
Ther is no thing in degree superlatyfe
As seith senek abouyn an humble wyfe
Suffre thi wyfis tunge as catoun byt
She shal comaunde and þou shal suffre yt
And yit she wil obeye of curtesye
A wyfe is keper of thyne husbandrye
Weel may the seek man bewayle and wepe
Ther ther is no wyfe the hous for to kepe
I warne the yif thou wilt wisely wirche
Loue wel thi wyfe as criste louyth his chirche
Yif louest thi self thou louys thi wyfe
No man hatith his flessh but in his lyfe
He fostrith yt ; and ther to I bydde the
Cherissh thi wyfe or thou shal neuer thee
Husbond and wyfe what so men say
Of worldly folk holdyn the right way
Thei been so knytte ther may no harme betyde
And namely vppon the wyfes syde
For whiche this Ianuary as I yow tolde
Considred hath in witte his dayes olde
The lusty lyfe the vertuous quyetee
That is in mariage hony sweete
And for his frendis on a day he sent
To telle hem the effecte of his entent
With face he hath hem this tale told
And seid freendis I am hoore and old
And almost god wot at my pittys brynke
Vppon my self sum what most me thynke
I haue my body folily dispendid
Blissid be god that yt shal be amendid
For I wil be certeyn a weddid man
And that in al the haste that I can
Vnto sum mayde fayre and tendre of age
I pray yow shapith for my mariage
Al subitanly for I wil not abyde
And I wil fonde to espy on my side
To whom that I may be weddid hastely
But for als mych as yee been to me frendly
Yee shuld rather such a thing espyen
Than I ; and where me were best to alyen
But of one thing warne I yow my frendis deere
I wil non old wyfe haue in no in no manere
She shal not passe sixtene yeer certeyn
Old fissh and yong flessh þat wold I fayn
Bettyr is qd he a pike than a pykerel
And bettir is than old boef tendre tendrew veel . .
I wil no womman xxti yeer of age
Yt nys but benestraw and gret forage
And eke thise old wyfes god yt wot
They can so mych craft of wadis bot
So mych brokyn harme whan þat hem lyst
That with hem shuld I neuyr lyf in rest
For sundry scolys makyn subtyle clerkis
A womman of many scolis a clerk is
But certanly a yong thing may men guye
Right as men may warme wex and wᵗith handis plye
For I sey yow pleynly in this cause
I wil non olde wyfe Right for this cause
For yif so were that I had such myschaunce
That I in here couth haue no pleasaunce
Than shuld I lede my lyfe in aduoutrye
And so streight to the deuyl whan I dye
Ne childryn shuld I non of hir getyn
Yit were me leuyr houndis hadde me etyn
Than that myn heritage shuld falle
In straunge handis and thus I telle yow alle
I doute not I knowe the cause why
That men shuld wedde ; and forthermore wot I
Ther spekith many a man of mariage
That wot no more of yt þan wot my page
For which cause men shuld take a wyfe
Yif he may not be chaast by his lyfe
Take hym a wyfe with gret deuocyoun
By cause of leefful precreacyoun
Of children to the honoᵘur of god aboue
And not only for paramoᵘur ne for loue
And for thei shuld lecchery eschewe
And yeld there dettys whils þat þei are newe
Outhir for ilk of them shuld help othir
In myscheef as a sustir shal the brothir
And lyue in chaastite ful heuynly
But syrs by your leue that am not I .
For god be thankid I dar make avaunt
I feele my lymes stark and sufficiaunt
To doon al that a man be longith to
I wot my self best what I may do
Þough I be hore I fare as dooth a tree
That blossomyth er that the frute I waxen bee
A blossemyd tree is not drye ne ded
I noughwhere hore but on my hed
Myn hert and my lymmes been als grene
As laurer þurgh the yeer is for to seene
And sithen yee haue herd al myn entent
I pray yow to my wil that yee assent
Dyuerse men dyuersely seide hym told
Of mariage many an ensample old
Sum blamyd yt sum praysid yt certayn
But at the last shortly for to seyn
As alday fallith altercacyoun
Betwix frendis in disputacyoun
Ther fel a stryfe betwix his brethyrn two
Of which that one clepid was placebo
And Iustinus soothly clepid was that othir
Placebo seid O Ianuary leef brothir
Ful lytil nede had yee my lord so deere
Councel to aske of any that is here
But that yee be so ful of sapience
That yow ne lyketh for your hygh prudence
To weyue fro the wurd of salamon
This wurd seid he vnto vs euerichon
Wuke al thing by councel thus seid he
And than shal thou not repent the .
But though that salomon spech such a wurd
Myn owne deer brothir and my lord
So wistly my soule god bringe to rest
I hold your owne councel is the best
For brothir myn of me take this motyfe
I haue now been a courtman al my lyfe
And god wot þough I vnwurthi bee
I haue stondyn in ful hygh degree
Aboutyn lordis in ful gret eastate
Yit had I neuyr with non of hem debate
I neuyr hem contraryed truly
I wot wel that my lord can more than I .
What that he said I held yt firme and stable
I said the same or ellis thing symylable
A ful gret foly yt is to any counseillour
That seruyth any lord of hygh honour
That dar presume or ellis think yt
That his counsel shuld passe his lordis wit
Nay lordis be no folys by my fay
Yee haue your self spoke this day
So high sentence so hool and so weel
That I consent and conferme yt euery deel
Yoᵘur wurdis and al your opnioun
By god ther is no man in al this toun
Ne in ytayl couth bettir haue seid
Cryste holdith hym of this ful wel payd
And trewly yt is an high curage
Of any man that fallyn is in to age
To take a yong wyfe by my fadir kynne
Your hert hengith vppon a mery pynne
Dooth now in this maner thus as yow lest
For fynally I holde yt for the best
Iustinus that ay satte and herde
Right in this wyse to placebo he answerde
Now good brothir be pacyent I yow pray
Sithen yee haue seid and herkyn what I say
Seneca among othir thingys wyse
Seith that a man ought hym right wel avyse
To whom he gyuyth his lond or his catel
And sithen I ought to avyse me wel
To whom I gyf me good away fro me
Wel more I aught to avyse me
To whom I gyf my body for alwey
I warne yow wel yt is no childes pley
To take a wyfe without aduysement
Men must enquere this is myn entent
Wheithir she be wyse or sobre or dronklew
Or prowd or lewde or othir way a shrew
A chider or a wastour of thi good
Or riche or pouer or ellis the man is wood
Al þough yt be so that no man fynde shal
Non in this world that trottith hool in al
No maner of beste such as men can deuyse
But neuer the lesse yt ought ynough to suffise
With any wyfe yif so were þat she hadde
Mo good maners than vicys badde
And al this askith leyser for to enquere
For god yt wot I haue wept many a tere
Ful pryuely sithen I hadde a wyfe
Prayse who so wil a weddid mannys lyfe
Certeyn I fynd in yt not but cost and care
And obseruauncys of alle blissis bare
And yit god wot my neighbours a boute
And namely of wommen many a route
Seyn that I haue the most stedfast wyfe
And eke the mekest on that berith lyfe
But I wot best where wringith me my sho
Yee may for me right as yew likith doo
Avisith yow ; yee been a man of age
How that yee entryn in to mariage
And namely with a yong wyfe and a fayre
By hym that made watyr erth and ayre
This yongest man that is in al this route
Is besy ynough to bringe yt aboute
To haue his wyfe allone trustith me
Yee shul not please hir fully yeeris three
This is to seyn to doon hir pleasaunce
A wyfe askith ful many an obseruaunce
I pray yow that yee bee not euyl apaid
Wel qd this Ianuary and hauys þou al said
A straw for thi senec and for thi prouerbis
I count not a panyer ful of herbis
Of scole termes ; for wyser men than thou
As thou hast herd ; consentyn doon right now
To my purpose placebo what sey yee
I sey yt is a cursid man quoth he
That lettith matrimony sikerly
And with that wurd thei resyn subtanly
And been assentid fully that he shuld
Be weddid where hym lyst and whan he wold
The fantasye and the besy curiousnesse
From day to day gan in the soule enpresse
Of Ianuary about his mariage
Many a fayre shappe and many a fayre visage
Ther passith thurgh his hert nyght by nyght
As who so took a myrour polisshid bright
And sette yt in a comoun market place
Than shuld he see many a figure pace
By his myrour in the same wyse
Saw Ianuary in which his hert wold deuyse
Of maydenys which that dwellyd besyde
He wist not where he myght abyde
For þough þat one haue beaute in hir face
An othir standith so in the poeplis grace
For hir sadnesse and hir benignyte
That of the poeple grettest voice had she
An othir is riche and hath a badde name
But neuyr the lesse betwix ernest and game .
He at the last appoyntid hym on one
And lat alle othir from here hert is gone
And chese hir of hys owne auctoritee
For loue is blynd alway and may not see
And whan that he was in his bed brought
He purtrayd in his hert and in his thought
Hir fressh beaute and hir age tendre
Hir myddil smal hir armys long and sklendre
Hir wyse gouernaunce hir gentilnesse
Hir wommanly beryng and hir sadnesse
And whan that he was to hir condescendid
Hym thought his eleccyou myght not be amendid
For whan that he hym self concluded hadde
Hym thought alle othir mennys wyttis so badde
That impossible yt were to replye
Ageyn his eleccyon this was his fantasye
He sent to his frendis at his Instaunce
And prayd hem to doon hym that plesaunce
That hastily thei wold to hym come
He wold abbregge hir labour al and some
Hem nedith no more for hym to go ne ryde
He was appoyntid where he wold abyde
Placebo come and eke his frendis sone
And althir furst he prayd hem of a bone
That non of hem non argument shuld make
Ageyns his purpos that he hath take
Which purpos was pleasaunt to god said he
And verray ground of his prosperyte
He said ther was a mayde in that toun
Whiche that of beaute had gret Renoun

Whan that the preest to yow my body bond
Wherfore I wil answere in this manere
With leue of yow my lord so deere
I pray god that dawe neuer that day
That I ne sterve as foule as womman may
Yif euer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Or ellis enpayre so my name
That I be fals ; and yif I do that lakke
Do strype me and put me in a sakke
And in the next ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentil womman and no wenche
Whi speke yee thus ; but men been euer vntrewe
And wommen haue þei repreuyd euer of newe
Yee can non othir contynaunce I leue
But euer speke to vs of vntrust and repreue
And with that wurd she saw where damyan
Satte in the buske ; and kowgh she began
And with hir fingyr a signe made she
That damyan shuld clymbe vp in to a tre
That chargid was with frute and vp he hewent
For verraly he knewe al his entent
And euery signe that she couth make
Wel bettir than Ianuary hir owne make
For in a lettre she had told hym al
Of this mater how that he wirche shal
And thus I lete hym sytte vpon the pley
This Ianuary romyng and also may
Bright was the day and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun his stremys hath sent
To glade euery floure with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminis as I gesse
But lytil of his declaracyoun
Of cancer Iouis exaltacioun
And befel that bright morwe tyde
That in the gardyn in the ferther side
Pluto that is the kyng of fayrye
And many a lady in his compaignye
Folwyng his wyfe queene proserpina
Which that he rauysshid out of ethena
Whils that she gadrid flourys in a mede
In claudian yee may the history rede
How in his grysly cart he hir sette
This kyng of fayrie doun hym sette
Vppon a benke of turphis fayre and grene
And anon thus seid he to his queene
My wyfe qd he ther may no wight sey nay
The experience preuyth yt euery day
The tresoun which that womman doos to man
Ten hundrith þousand historyes telle I can
Notable of your vntruthe and wrecchidnesse
O salamon richest of al richesse
Fulfillid of sapience and of worldly glory
Ful wurthi are thi wurdis to be in memory
To euery wight that wit and reson can
Thus preysid yit the bounte of a man
Among a thousand men yit fond I one
But of alle wommen yit fonde I neu non
Thus said this kyng þat knewe yoᵘur wykkidnesse
And Ihc filius syrach as I gesse
Ne spekith of yow but seldom Reuerence
The wild fyre and a corrupt pestilence
So falle vppon your bodyes yit this nyght
Ne see yee not this honourable knyght
Be cause allas that he is blynd and old
His owne man yit shal make hym cukwold
Lo where he sittis the lecchour in the tree
Now wil I graunt graunthym of my maieste
Vnto this olde wurthi blynd knyght
That he shal haue ageyn his eyen sight
Whan that his wyfe wil doon hym vilany
Than shal he knowe al hir harlotry
Bothe in repreef of hir and othir mo
Yee shal qd proserpyna and shal yee so
Now by my modir soule sir I swere
That I shal gyf hir sufficient answere
And to alle wommen aftir for hir sake
That þough thei be in any gyle I take
With face bold thei shal hem self excuse
And bere hem doun that wold hem accuse
For lakke of answere non of vs shal dyen
Al þough yee had seen a thing with boþe yoᵘur eyen
Yit shal we so yt visage hardily
And wepe and swere and chide subtilly
That yee shul been als lewde as gees
What rekkith me of yoᵘur auctoritees
I wote wel that this Iew this salomon
Fond of vs wommen folys many on
But though he fond no good womman
Ther hath found many an othir man
Wommen ful good trewe and vertuous
Wittenesse of hym that duellys in cristis hous
With martyrdome that preuyd hir constauce
The Romayn gestis makyn Remembraunce
Of many a verry trewe wyfe also
But sir be not wroth al though yt be so
That he seid he fond no good womman
I pray take the sentence of man
He ment thus that in soueraigne bounte
Ne is non good nouthir he ne she
But for the verray god that nys but one
What make yee so mych of salomon
What þough he made a temple goddis hous ;
What þough he were riche and glorious ;
So made he eke a temple of fals goddis
Who myght doo a thing þat more forbed is ;
Parde als fayre as yee his name enplaastre
He was a lecchour and eke an Idolastre
And in his elde he verray god forsooke
And yif god ne hadde as saith the booke
Sparid hym for his fadir sake he shuld
Haue lost his Regne ; sauf þat god ne wold
I sette nought of al the vilanye
That he of wommen wrot a buttyrflye
I am a womman nede mot I speke
Or ellis swelle til my hert breke
For sithen he said that we been iangleressis
As euyr mot I brouke wel my tressis
I shal not spare for no curtasye
To speke hym harme þat spekith vs vilanye
Dame qd this pluto be no lenger wroth
I gyf yt vp ; but sithen I swore and oth
That I wold graunt hym his sight ageyn
My wurd shal stand that warne I yow certeyn
Iam a kyng yt sittith me not to lye
And I am a queene qd she of fayrye
Hir answer shal she haue I vndirtake
Lat vs no mo wurdis of yt make
For sooth I wil no lenger yow contrary
Now lat vs turne ageyn to Ianuary
That in the gardyn with his fayre may
Syngith meryer than a popyn Iay
Yow loue I best and shal and othir non
So long aboute the aleys is he gon
Til he come ageyn thilk pirye
Where as this damyan sittith ful merye
And hygh among the fressh leuys grene
This fressh may that is bright and shene
Gan for to sighen and said allas my syde
Now sir quoth she for ought that may betyde
I most haue of thise perys that I se
Or I most dye so sore longith me
To etyn of the smale peris grene
Help for hir loue that is of heuyn queene
I telle yow wel a womman in my plyte
May haue to frute so gret an appetyte
That she may dye but yif of yt haue
Allas quoth she that I ne had here a knaue
That couth clymbe ; allas allas quoth he
For I am blynd ; ye sir no force qd she
So that I my feet myght sette vppon your bakke
Certys quoth he therin shal be no lakke
Myght I yow help with myn hert blood
He stoupid doun and on his bakke she stood
And caught by a twist and vp she goth
Ladyes I pray yow that yee be not wroth
I can not glose I am a rude man
And subitanly anon this damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok and in he throng
And whan that pluto saw this gret wrong
To Ianuary he gaf ageyn his sight
That he myght se als wel as euer he myght
And whan that he had caught his sight ageyn
Ne was ther neuer man of thing so fayn
But on his wyfe his thought was euer mo
And to the tree he cast his eyen two
And saw that damyan his wyfe had dressid
In such wyse as may not be expressid
But yif I wold speke vncurtayslye
And vp he gaf a roryng and a crye
As dooth the modir whan the child shal dye
Out help harrow allas he gan to crye
O strong lady stoor what doost thou
And she answerd ʆser/sir what eylith yow
Haue pacience and reson in your mynde
I haue yow helpid of bothe yoᵘur eyen blynde
Vppon peril of my soule I shal not lyen
This was me taught to hele with yoᵘur eyen
Was ther no thing bettir to make yow to see
Than stroglyng with a man vppon a tree
God wot I did yt in ful good entent
Strouglyng qd he ; but algate in yt went
God gyf yow bothe a shamys deth to dyen
Yee did amys I saw yt with myn eyen
And ellis be I hangid by the hals
Than is qd she my medicyne al fals
For certanly yif that yee myght see
Yee wold not sey thise wurdis to me
Yee haue som glymryng and no ꝑper/parfecte sight
I se qd he als wel as euer I myght
Thankid be god with bothe myn eyen two
And by my trouthe me thought yee didyn so
Yee ; the mase the mase good ʆser/sir qd she
This thank haue I for that I made yow see
Allas ʆser/sir quoth she that euer I was so kynde
Now dame qd he lat yt passe out of mynde
Come doun my loue and yif I haue myssaid
God help me so as I am euyl a paid
But by my fadirs soule I wend þat I had seen
How that this damyan had by the lyen
And that thi smok had lyggyn vppon thi brest
Yee sir qd she yee may wene as yow lest
But sir a man that wakith out of his sleep
He may not subitanly wel take keepe
Vppon a thing ne see yt so perfectely
Til he be adawid verrayli
Right so a man þat long hath blynd be
Ne may not subtanly so wel see
Furst whan his sight is comyn newe ageyn
As he that hath a day or two seyn
Til that youre sight sattlid be a while
Ther may ful many a sight yow begyle
Be war I pray yow for by heuyn kyng
Ful many a man wenyth to se a thing
That is al an othir than yt semyth
He that mysconceyueth mysdemyth
And with that wurd she lepith doun fro þe þetree
This Ianuary who is glad but he
He kissith hir and clippith hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stryketh hir ful softe
And to his palace hom he hath hir lad
Now god good men I pray you to be glad
Thus endid is my tale of Ianuary
God blisse vs and his modir seynt mary

div.l:
Explicit fabula mercatoris ⁊and sub-
sequenter incipit prohemium fabule
Armigeri hoc modo sequente
Ey goddis mercy seid oure host tho
Now such a wyfe I pray god kepe me fro
Lo such sleightis and subtilitees
In wommen been ; and ay as besy as bees
Been thei ; vs sely men for to deceyue
And from a sooth ay wil thei weyue
Ey this merchauntz tale preuyth weel
But doutles als trew as any steel
I haue a trewetrewe wyfe þough she poure be
But of hir blabbyng a shrewe is she
And yit she hath an hep of vices mo
Therof no force lat alle such þinges go
But wot yee what in councel be yt seid
Me rewith sore that I am to hir teyd
For yif I shuld rekne euery vice
Whiche that she hath Iwis I were to nyce
And cause whi ; yt shuld reportid be
And told to hir of sum of this meyne
Of whom yt nedith not to declare
Sithen wommen can outyn such chaffare
And eke my wytte suffiseth not therto
To telle al wherfore my tale is doo
Esquyer com neer yif that yoᵘur wille be
And say som what for certys yee
Can theron as mekil as any man
Nay fro quoth he but such thingys as I can
With hertly wil I wil not be Rebelle
Ageyn your lust a tale for to telle
Hold me excusid yif I speke amys
My wil is good and my tale is this

Explicit prohemium fabule Armi-
geri ⁊and subsequenter narrat fabulam
suam hoc modo sequente .
(base) Here bigynneth the Squiers tale
(base) Incipit fabula Armigeri
(base) AT Sarray in the land of Tartarye
(base) Ther dwelte a kyng that werreyed Russye
(base) Thurgh which ther deyde many a doghty man
(base) This noble kyng was clepid Kambyuskan
(base) Which in his tyme was of so greet renoun
(base) That ther nas nowher in no Regioun
(base) So excellent a lord in alle thyng
(base) Hym lakked noght that longed to a kyng
(base) As of the secte of which that he was born
(base) He kepte his lay to which that he was sworn
(base) And ther to he was hardy wys and riche
(base) Pietous and Iust and eueremoore yliche
(base) Sooth of his word benigne and honurable
(base) Of his corage as any Centre stable
(base) Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous
(base) As any Bachiler of al his hous
(base) A fair persone he was and fortunat
(base) And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
(base) That ther nas no wher swich another man
(base) This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan

terminis et ideo ad presens preter-

xN feith esquyer thou hast the wel quytte
I preyse gentilly and right wel thi wytte
Quoth the frankleyn consideryng thi yowthe
So felyngly thou spekist sir I alow the
As to my dome ther nys non that is here
Of eloquence that shal be thi pere
Yif that thou lyue god gif the good chaunce
And in vertu send the contynuaunce
For of thi speche I haue gret deynte
I haue a sone and by the trynytee
I had leuer than xxᵗⁱ pound wurth of land
Þough yt were right now fallyn in my hand
He were a man of such discrecyoun
As that yee been fy on possessioun
But yif aman be vertuous with al
I haue my sone snybbid and yit I shal
For he to vertues lystith not to entende
But for to play at dyse and to dispende
And lese al that he hath is his vsage
And he had leuer talkyn with a page
Than to comown with any gentil wight
Where he myght lere gentilnesse of right
A strawe for oure gentilnesse qd oure host
What frankleyn sir parde wel thou wost
That ich of yow mot tellyn at the lest
A tale or two ; or brekyn his byhest
That know I wel qd the frankleyn certeyn
I pray yow haue yt at no disdeyn
Though I to this man spak a wurd or two
Telle thou thi tale without wurdis mo .
Gladly qd he sir host I wil obeye
Vnto your wil now herkyn what I seye
I wil not yow contrary in no wyse
As ferforth as that my wytte wil suffice
I pray to god that yt may please yow
Than wot I wel that yt is good ynowgh

div.l: (base) Incipit slog9 . de le Frankeleyne .
(base) Thise olde gentil Britons in hir dayes
(base) Of diuerse auentures maden layes
(base) Rymeyed in hir firste Briton tonge
(base) Whiche layes with hir Instrumentz they songe
(base) Or ellis redden hem for hire plesaunce
(base) And oon of hem haue I in remembraunce
(base) Which I shal seyn with good wyl as I kan
(base) But sires by cause I am a burel man
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) At my bigynnyng first I yow biseche
(base) Haue me excused of my rude speche
(base) I lerned neuere Rethorik certeyn
(base) Thyng that I speke It moot be bare and pleyn
(base) I sleep neuere in the Mount of parnaso
(base) Ne lerned Marcus Tullius Scithero
(base) Colours ne knowe I none withouten drede
(base) But swiche colours as growen in the mede
(base) Or ellis swiche as men dye or peynte
(base) Colours of Rethoryk they ben to queynte
(base) My Spirit feeleth nat of swich matere
(base) But if yow list my tale shul ye heere
(base) In Armorik that called is Britayne
(base) Ther was a knyght that louede and dide his payne
(base) To serue a lady in his beste wise
(base) And many a labour many a gret emprise
(base) He for his lady wroghte er she were wonne
(base) For she was oon the faireste vnder Sonne
(base) And eek ther to come of so heigh kynrede
(base) That wel vnnethes dorste this knyght for drede
(base) Telle hire his wo his peyne and his distresse
(base) But atte laste she for his worthynesse
(base) And namely for his meke obeysance
(base) Hath swich a pitee caught of his penance
(base) That priuely she fel of his acord
(base) To taken hym for hir housbonde and hir lord
(base) Of swich lordshipe as men han ouer hir wyues
(base) And for to lede the moore in blisse hir lyues
(base) Of his fre wyl he swoor hire as a knyght
(base) That neuere in al his lyf he day ne nyght
(base) Ne sholde vpon hym take no maistrye
(base) Agayn hir wyl ne kithe hire Ialousye
(base) But hire obeye and folwe hir wyl in al
(base) As any louere to his lady shal
(base) Saue that the name of soueraynetee
(base) That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
(base) She thonked hym and with ful gret humblesse
(base) She seyde sire sith of youre gentilesse
(base) Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
(base) Ne wolde neuere god bitwix vs tweyne
(base) As in my gilt were outher werre or stryf
(base) Sire I wol be youre humble trewe wyf
(base) Haue heer my trouthe til that myn herte breste
(base) Thus been they bothe in quiete and in reste
(base) For o thyng sires saufly dar I seye
(base) That freendes euerich oother moote obeye
(base) If they wol longe holden compaignye
(base) Loue wol nat be constreyned by maistrye
(base) Whan maistrie comth the god of loue anon
(base) Beteth his wynges and farwel he is gon
(base) Loue is a thyng as any spirit free
(base) Wommen of kynde desiren libertee
(base) And nat to been constreyned as a thral
(base) And so doon men if I sooth seyn shal
(base) Looke who that moost is pacient in loue
(base) He is at his auantage al aboue
(base) Pacience is an heigh vertu certeyn
(base) For it venquysseth as thise clerkes seyn
(base) Thynges that rigour sholde neuere atteyne
(base) For euery word men may nat chide or pleyne
(base) For yifs thei do yt is but in veyn
(base) Lerneth to suffre or ellis so moot I gon
(base) Ye shul it lerne wher so ye wole or non
(base) For in this world certeyn ther no wight is
(base) That he ne dooth or seith som tyme amys
(base) Ire siknesse or constellacioun
(base) Wyn wo or chaungyng of complexioun
(base) Causeth ful ofte to doon amys or speken
(base) On euery wrong a man may nat be wreken
(base) But euery wrong mot redressid be
(base) Sum what by pacience and not al by cruelte
(base) After the tyme moste be temperaunce
(base) To euery wight that kan on gouernaunce
(base) And therfore hath this wise worthy knyght
(base) To lyue in ese suffraunce hire bihight
(base) And she to hym ful wisly gan to swere
(base) That neuere sholde ther be defaute in here
(base) Here may men seen an humble wys acord
(base) Thus hath she take hir seruant and hir lord
(base) Seruant in loue and lord in mariage
(base) Thanne was he bothe in lordshipe and seruage
(base) Seruage nay but in lordshipe aboue
(base) Sith he hath bothe his lady and his loue
(base) His lady certes and his wyf also
(base) The which that lawe of loue acordeth to
(base) And whan he was in this prosperitee
(base) Hom with his wyf he gooth to his contree
(base) Nat fer fro Pedmark ther his dwellyng was
(base) Wher as he lyueth in blisse and in solas
(base) Who koude telle but he hadde wedded be

div.l: (base) The ioye the ese and the prosperitee
(base) That is bitwix an housbonde and his wyf
(base) A yeer and moore lasted this blisful lyf
(base) Til that the knyght of which I speke of thus
(base) That of kairrud was clepid Arueragus
(base) Shoop hym to goon and dwelle a yeer or twayne
(base) In Engelond that clepid was ek Britayne
(base) To seke in armes worship and honour
(base) For al his lust he sette in swich labour
(base) And dwelled ther two yeer the book seith thus
(base) Now wol I stynte of this Arueragus
(base) And speke I wole of Dorigene his wyf
(base) That loueth hir housbonde as hir hertes lyf
(base) For his absence wepeth she and siketh
(base) As doon thise noble wyues whan hem liketh
(base) She moorneth waketh waileth fasteth pleyneth
(base) Desir of his presence hir so destreyneth
(base) That al this wide world she set at noght
(base) Hir freendes whiche that knowe hir heuy thoght
(base) Conforten hire in al that euer they may
(base) They prechen hire they telle hire nyght and day
(base) That causelees she sleeth hirself allas
(base) And euery confort possible in this cas
(base) They doon to hire withal hir bisynesse
(base) Al for to make hire leue hir heuynesse
(base) By proces as ye knowen euerichoon
(base) Men may so longe grauen in a stoon
(base) Til som figure ther Inne emprented be
(base) So longe han they conforted hire til she
(base) Receyued hath by hope and by resoun
(base) The emprentyng of hir consolacioun
(base) Thurgh which hir grete sorwe gan aswage
(base) She may nat alwey duren in swich rage
(base) And eek Arueragus in al this care
(base) Hath sent hire lettres hom of his welfare
(base) And that he wole come hastily agayn
(base) Or ellis hadde this sorwe hir herte slayn
(base) Hire freendes sawe hir sorwe gan to slake
(base) And preyde hire on knees for goddes sake
(base) To come and romen hire in compaignye
(base) Awey to dryue hir derke fantasye
(base) And finally she graunted that requeste
(base) For wel she saw that it was for the beste
(base) Now stood hir Castel faste by the See
(base) And often with hir freendes walketh she
(base) Hir to disporte vpon the bank an heigh
(base) Wher as she many a Ship and Barge seigh
(base) Seillynge hir cours wher as hem liste go
(base) But thanne was that a parcel of hir wo
(base) For of hirself ful ofte allas seith she
(base) Is ther no ship of so manye as I se
(base) Wol bryngen hom my lord thanne were myn herte
(base) Al warisshed of hise bittre peynes smerte
(base) Another tyme there wolde she sitte and thynke
(base) And caste hir eyen downward fro the Brynke
(base) But whan she seigh the grisly Rokkes blake
(base) For verray fere so wolde hir herte quake
(base) That on hir feet she myghte hir noght sustene
(base) Thanne wolde she sitte adoun vpon the grene
(base) And pitously in to the See biholde
(base) And seyn right thus with sorweful sikes colde
(base) Eterne god that thurgh thy purueiance
(base) Ledest the world by certeyn gouernance
(base) In ydel as men seyn ye no thyng make
(base) But lord thise grisly feendly Rokkes blake
(base) That semen rather a foul confusioun
(base) Of werk than any fair creacioun
(base) Of swich a parfit wys god and a stable
(base) Why han ye wroght this werk vnresonable
(base) For by this werk South North ne West ne Est
(base) Ther nys yfostred man ne bryd ne beest
(base) It doth no good to my wit but anoyeth
(base) Se ye nat lord how mankynde it destroyeth
(base) An hundred thousand bodies of mankynde
(base) Han Rokkes slayn al be they nat in mynde
(base) Which mankynde is so fair part of thy werk
(base) That thow it madest lyk to thyn owen merk
(base) Thanne semed it ye hadde a greet chiertee
(base) Toward mankynde but how thanne may it be
(base) That ye swiche menes make it to destroyen
(base) Whiche menes do no good but euere anoyen
(base) I woot wel clerkes wol seyn as hem leste
(base) By argumentz that al is for the beste
(base) Thogh I ne kan the causes nat yknowe
(base) But thilke god that made wynd to blowe
(base) As kepe my lord this my conclusioun
(base) To clerkes lete I al disputisoun
(base) But wolde god that alle thise Rokkes blake
(base) Were sonken in to helle for his sake
(base) Thise Rokkes sleen myn herte for the feere
(base) Thus wolde she seyn with many a pitous teere
(base) Hir freendes sawe that it was no disport

div.l: (base) To romen by the See but disconfort

(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Lordyngis qd he in chirche whan I preche
I peyne me for to haue an hauntand speche
And rynge yt out as rounde as gos a belle
For I can al by rote that I telle
My theme is alwey one and euer was
Radix malorum cupiditas
Furst I pronounce fro whens þat I come
And than my bullys shew I alle and some
Oure lege lordis seal on my patent
That shewe I furst my body for to warent
That no man be so bold preest ne clerk
Me to disturbe of cristis holy werk
And aftir that telle I forth my talys
Bullys of popis and of cardynalys
Of patriarkis and of bisshopis I shewe
And in latyn speke I wurdis a fewe
To sauour with my predicacyoun
And for to stere hem to deuoyoun
Than shewe I forth my long cristal stonys
I crammyd ful of cloutys and of bonys
Reliquees thei been as wenyn thei ichon
Than haue I in latun a shuldir bon
Which that was of an holy iewis sheope
Good men sey I takis of my wurdis kepe
Yif that this bon be wasshen in any welle
Yif cow or kalf sheep or oxe swelle
Yif that any worme hym ete or any worme stonge
Take watir of that welle and wassh his tonge
And yt is hool anon ; and forthermore
Of pokkis and of skabbis and euery sore
Shal euery sheep be hool that of this welle
Drynkith a draught ; take keep eke what I telle
Yif that the goodman that the bestes owith
Wil euery morwe or that the cokke crowith
Fastyng drynke of this welle a draught
As thilk holy iewe or his elders taught
His bestis and his store shal multiplye
And sir also yt helith ielousye
For though a man be falle in ielous rage
Lat make with this watir his potage
And neuer shal he more his wyfe mystrust
Though yt be so that of hir default he wist
Al though she had takyn preestis two or three
Here is a myteyn also as yee may see
He that his hand wil putte in this myteyn
He shal haue multiplyeng of his greyn
Whan he hath sowyn be yt whete or otys
So that he gyf me penyes or grotys
And men and wommen of one þing warne I yow
Yif any wight be in this chirche now
That hath doon synne horrible that he
Dar not for shame of yt shryuyn be
Or any womman be she yong or old
That has made hir husbond cukkewold
Which folk shal haue no power ne no grace
To offre to my reliquees in this place
And who so findith hem out of such blame
Thei wil come vp and offre in goddis name
And I assoyle hem by auctorte
Which that the bulle has grauntid vnto me
By this gaude haue I wonne euery yeere
An hundreth marc sithen I was a pardonere
I stand like a clerk in a pulpyt
And whan the lewde poeple is doun set
I preche so as yee herd before
And telle an hundrith iapis more
Than peyne I for to strecche forth þe nekke
And est and west vppon the poeple I bekke
As doos a dowe vppon a berne sittyng
My handis and my tonge gon so yernyng
That it is ioye to see my besynesse
Of auarice and of such cursidnesse
Is al my preching for to make hem free
To gif here penyes and namely vnto me
For myn entent is not but for to wynne
And no thyng for correccyon of synne
I rekke neuer whan that thei be buryed
Though þeir soulys wich þe deuyl be wyryed
For certis many a predicacyon
Comyth ofte tyme of ille intencyon
Sum for pleasaunce of folk and for flaterye
To be avaunsid by Ipocrisye
And sum for vayn glory and sum for hate
For whan I dar not othir ways debate
Than wil I strykyn hem with my tonge smert
In preching so that he shal not astert
To be diffamyd falsly yif that he
Haue trespacid to my brethir or to me
Forth I telle not the propir name
For men shal knowe wel that yt is the same
By signys and by othir circumstaunce
Thus quyte I folk that doon vs displesaunce
Thus spytte I out venym vndir the hewe
Of holynesse ; to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myne entent I wil yow deuyse
I preche of no thing but of couetyse
Therfore my theme is yit and euer was
Radix malorum cupiditas
Thus can I preche ageyn the same vice
Which that I vse and that is auaryce
But þough my self be gilty of that synne
Yit can I make othir folk to twynne
From auarice and sore hem repent
But that is not my principal entent
I preche no thing but for couetyse
Of this mater yt owith now to suffice
Than telle I hem ensaunplis manyon
Of old histories long tyme a gon
For lewde poeple loue talys olde
Which thei can wel reportyn and holde
What trowe yee that whils I may preche
And wynne gold and siluer for to teche
That I wil leuyn in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought yt not truly
For I wil preche and begge in sundre landis
I wil not do no labour with my handis
Ne make baskettys and lyuyn therby
By cause I wil not beggyn ydilly
I wil non of the apostolis countrefete
I wil haue mony mele chese or whete
Al þough yt be gyfyn of the pouerest page
Or of the pouerest wydow in a village
Al þough hir childern shuld sterue for fam
Nay I wil drynk lycour of the wyne
And haue a ioly wench in euery toun
But herkyn lordyngis my conclusioun
Your likyng is that I shal telle a tale
Now I haue dronkyn a draught of corny ale
By god I hope I shal telle yow a thing
That shal by resou been at your likyng
For þough my self be a ful vicious man
A merveillous tale yit I yow telle can
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now hold your pees my tale I wil begynne
