incipit fabula perdonarij . sic
In flaundris whilom was a compaigny
Of yong folk that hauntid foly
As ryot hasard stuhous and tauernys
Where as with harpis lutys or geternys
Thei daunse and pley at dyse bothe day ⁊and nyght
And ete also and drunk ouer theyr myght
Thurgh whiche thei doon the deuyl sacrifice
Within the deuyls temple in cursid wise
By superfluyte abhomynable
Here othes been so gret and dampnable
That yt is grisly to here hem swere
Oure blisseful lordis body thei al to tere
As þough the iewis rent hym not ynough
And ilk of hem at othir synnys lough
And right anon ther cam kembesters
Fetyse and smal and yong frutesteris
Syngers with harpis baudis wafreris
Which been verraly the deuyls officeris
To kyndle and blowe the fyre of lecchery
That is a nette to glutony
The holy wrytte take I to my wittenesse
That lecchery is in wyne and dronknesse
Vnde paulus nolite inebriari vino ⁊and oᵒ
Lo how that drunkyn loth vnkyndly
Lay by his doughtris two vnwittyngly
So dronkyn he was he nyst what he wrought
Heroude who so weel the history sought
Whan that he with wyne was replet at his feste
Right at his owne table gaf he his beheste
To sleen Iohn the baptist ful giltles
Senec seith a good wurd doutles
He said he can no difference fynde
Betwxe a man that out is of his mynde
And a man that is dronkelew
But that woodnesse fallyng in a shrew
Perseuerith langer than dooth drunkenesse
O glotony ful of cursidnesse
O cause furst of oure conclusioun
O original of oure dampnacyoun
Til crist had bought vs with his blood ageyn
Lo how deere shortly for to seyn
Abought was that cursid vilany
Corrupt was al this world for glotony
Adam oure fadir and his wyfe also
From paradise to labour and to wo
Were dryuyn ; for that vice yt is no drede
For whils that adam fastid as I rede
He was in paradise ; and whan þat he
Ete of the frute deffendid of the tre
Anon he was out cast to wo and to peyne
O glotony wel aught vs on the pleyne
O . wist a man how many maledyes
Folwyn of excesse and of glotonyes
He wold be the more meusurable
Of his dyete syttyng at his table
Allas the short throte the tendre mouthe
Makith that est and west north and south
In erthe in ayere in watyr man to swynke
To gete a glotou deynteth mete ⁊and drynke
Of this mater o paule wel can þou trete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal destruyn bothe as poule sayth
Allas a foule thing is yt by my fayth
To say this wurd and foulere the dede
Whan man so drynkith of the white ⁊and rede
That of his throte he makis his pryuee
Thurgh the cursid superfluytee
The apostle wepyng seith ful pitously
Ther walkyn many of the which told yow haue I
I say yt is not wepyng with pitous voice
Ther been enemyes on cristis croyce
Of which the ende seith wombe is here god
O wombe . o bely . O stynkyng kod
Ful fillid of dong and of corrupcyoun
At outhir ende of the ful foul is the soun
How gret cost and labour yt is to fynde
The cokys that stampe streyn and grynde
And turne substaunce in to accident
To fulfille al thi lycorouse talent
Out of the harde bonys knokke thei
The mary for thei cast nought awey
That may go thurgh the golet soft ⁊and swote
Of spicery of leefys bark and roote
Shal been his sauce made by delyte
To make hym yit a newe appetyte
But certis he that hath such delyces
Is ded whils that he lyuys in vicys
A lykerous thing is wyne ; and dronkenesse
Is ful of stryuyng and of wrecchidnesse
O drunke man disfigurid is thi face
Soure is thi breth foul art thou to enbrace
And thurgh thi drunkenesse semyth þe soun
Ay as þough thou seid sampsoun sampsoun
And god wot sampson drank neuer wyne
Thou fallist as yt were a stykkid swyne
Thi tonge is lost and al thyn honest cure
For verrey dronkenesse is verrey sepulture
Of mannys wit and his discrecyoun
In whom that drynk hath duāmcyoun
He can no counseil kepe yt is no drede
Now kepe yow fro the white and fro þe rede
And namely fro the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle in fissh strete or in chepe
This wyne of hispayne crepyth subtily
In othir wynes growyng fast by
Of which ther rysith such fumosite
That whan a man hath drunkyn draughtis thre
And wenyth that he be at hom in chepe
He is in hispayne right at þe toun of lepe
Nought at þe Rochel ne at burdeuxe toun
And then wil thei sey sampsoun sampsoun
But herknyth lordynges a wurd I yow pray
That alle the soueraigne actys dar I say
Of victoryes in the olde testament
Were doon thurgh god omnipotent
Lokith the bible and ther may yee yt lere
In many placys yif yee wil yt here
Loke attylla the gret conquerour
Dyed in his shippe with shame ⁊and dishonour
Bledyng ay at his nose in drunkenesse
A capitan shuld lyue in sobrenesse
And ouer al this avisith yow right wel
What was comaundid vnto lamuel
Not samuel but lamuel said I
Redith the bible and fyndith it expressely
Of wyne ; gyffyng to yow þat haue Iustice
No more of this for yt may wel suffice
And now that I haue spokyn of glotonye
Now wil deffende yow hasardye
Hasard is verrey modir of lesyngis
And of deceyt and cursid forsweryngis
Blaspheme of crist manslaughtre ⁊and wast also
Of catel and of tyme and forthermo
Yt is repreef and contrarye to honour
For to be holdyn a comoun hasardour
And euer the higher he is of eastate
The more is he hold desolate
Yif that a prince vse hasardye
In al his gouernaunce and his polecye
He is as by comoun opinioun
Yholdyn the lesse of Reputacyoun
Steelbon that was hold a wyse ambaxiatour
Was sent in to corinthe with ful gret honoᵘur
Fro lacedomye to make hir allyaunce
And whan he cam hym happenyd par chaunce
That alle the grettest that were of þat lande
Playng at the hasard he hem fande
For which as sone as yt myght be
He stale hym hom ageyn to his cuntre
And said there wil I not lese my mame
I wil not take on me so gret diffame
Yow for to alyen to any hasardourys
Sendith othir wyse ambaxiatourys
For by my trouthe I hadde wel leuer dye
Than I yow shuld to hasardours alye
For yee that been so glorious in honourys
Shal not alye yow with hasardourys
As by my wil ne as by my tretee
This wyse philosophre thus seid he
Loke eke the kyng demetrius
The kyng of parthes the book seith thus
Sent hym a payre of dyys in skorn
For he had vsid hasardye be forn
For whiche he sette his glory and renoun
At no valu or reputacyoun
Lordis may finde many an othir play
Honest ynowgh to dryue awey the day
Now wil I speke of othis fals and grete
A wurd or two as othir bokis trete
Gret swering is a thing abhomynable
And fals sweryng is yit a thing more repref
The hygh god forbad sweryng at al
Wittenesse of matheu but in especial
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieremye
Thou shal swere sooth thyne othis ⁊and not lye
And swere in doome and eke in rightwysnesse
Ydil sweryng is but wrecchidesse
Behold and see that in the furst table
Of hie goddis comaundement honourable
How that þe secunde comaundmēmt of hym is this
Take not my name in ydilnesse ne amys
Lo rathir he forbed sweryng
Than homicidie or many a cursid thing
I sey that by ordre thus yt standith
Þat know thei þat goddis pceptis vndirstandiþ
How that the secunde behest of god is that
And forthirmore I wil þe telle al plat
That vengeaunce shal not part fro his hous
That of his othis is so outragious
By cokkis precious hert and his naylis
And by the blood of criste that is in haylis
Seuene is my chaunce ⁊and thyn is synk ⁊and treye
By cokkis dere armys yif thou falsly pleye
This dagger shal to thi hert go
This frute comyth of the bicchid bonys two
Forswerīmg Ire falsnesse homycide
Now for the loue of crist that for vs dide
Letith your othis bothe gret and smale
But sirs now wil I telle forth my tale
Thise riottours thre of the which I telle
Long erst or pryme rong any belle
Were sette in a taverne for to drynke
And as thei satte thei herd a belle clynke
Beforn a corps was caryed to his graue
That one of hem gan calle to hym a knaue
Go bet qd he and aske redily
What corps is this that passit herby
And looke that thou report his name wel
Sir qd this boy yt nedith neuer a deel
Yt was me told or yee cam here two hourys
He was parde an old felawe of youris
And subtanly was he slayn this nyght
For drunke as he sat vppon his benke vpright
Ther come a pryuee theef men clepyn deth
That in this cuntre al the poeple sleeth
And with his spere he smot his hert in two
And went his way without wurdis mo
He hath a thousand slayn this pestilence
And mayster er yee come in his presence
Me thynk yt were full necessary
For to be war of such an aduersary
Beeth redy for to mete hym euermore
Thus taught me my dame I sey no more
By seynt mary seid the tauernere
The child saith sooth for he hath slayn this yeere
Hens ouer a myle within a gret village
Bothe man and womman child and page
I trowe his habitacyou be there
To been aduysid gret wisdam yt were
Or that he did a man a dishonour
Ya goddis armys quoth this riotour
Yt is such peril with hym for to mete
I shal hym seche by way and eke by strete
I make a vow to goddys digne bonys
Herkyn felawys we thre alle at onys
Lete ich of vs hold vp his hand to othir
And eủer/reich of vs becomyn othirs brothir
And we wil sleen þis ich fals traytour deth
He shal be slayn that so many sleeth
By goddis dignytee or yt be nyght
To gedir haue thei theire trouthis plight
To lyue and dye ich of hem for othir
As he were his owne sworn brothir
And vp thei stert al dronkyn in this rage
And forth thei gon toward that village
Of which the tauerner had spokyn beforn
And many a grysly oth than haue thei sworn
And cristis blissid body thei al to rent
Deth shal be ded yif that thei may hym hent
Whan thei haue gon not fully a myle
Right as thei wold haue trodyn ouer a style
An old pouer man with hem he mette
And ful mekely he hem grette
And said thus lordyngis god yow sant se
The proudest of thise ryottours thre
Answerd ageyn ; what carl with hard grace
What art thou al forwrappid sauf thi face
Whi lyuys thou so long in so gret age
This old man began to loke in his visage
And said thus ; for I can not fynde
A man though I walkid in to Inde
Nouthir in cytee ne in village
That wil chaunge his yougthe for myn age
And therfore mot I haue myn age stille
As long tyme as yt is goddis wille
Ne deth wil not allas haue my lyfe
Thus walke I lyke a rekkeles caytife
And on the grounde which is my moders gate
I knokke with my staffe bothe erly and late
And says leef modir lete me In
Lo how I want flessh blood and skyn
Allas whan shal my bonys be at rest
My modir with yow wold I chaunge my chest
That in my chambre long tyme hath be
Ya and in an hayre cloute to wrappe me
But yit to me she wil not do that grace
For which ful welkid and pale is my face
But sirs to yow yt is no curtasye
To speke to an old man vilanye
But yif I trespacyd in wurde or ellis in dede
Ageyn an old man hore vppon his hede
Yee shuld aryse ; wherfore I yow rede
In holy wryt your self yee may yt rede
Ne dooth vn to an old man no harme now
No more than yee wold þat men did to yow
In age ; yif that yee so long abyde
And god be with yow where that yee go or ryde
I mot go thider as I haue to go
Nay old cherl thou shalt not so
Sayde this othir hasardour anon
Thou departist not fro vs so soon
Thou spak right now of thilk traytoᵘur deth
That in this cuntre alle oure frendis sleth
As here my trouthe as thou art a spye
Telle where he is or thou shalt abye
By god and by the holy sacrament
For shortly thou art one of his assent
To sleen thise yong folk fals theef
Now sirs yif yee bee so leef
To fynde deth turnyth vp this crokid way
For in that groue I left hym by my fay
Vndir a tree and ther he wol abyde
Ne for your bost he wil hym no thing hide
Se yee that oke ; right ther yee shal hym fynde
God saue yow that bought ageyn man kynde
And yow amende ; thus said this old man
And euerich of thise riotours ran
Til thei come to the tre and there thei founde
Of floreyns fyne of gold conyd rounde
Welnygh vij . busshels as hem thought
No lenger than aftir deth thei sought
But ich of hem so glad was of that sight
For that the floreyns been so fayre and bright
That doun thei sette hem by the precyous hord
The wurst of he spak the furst wurd
Brothir quoth he take keep what I say
My witte is gret þough þat I bourd ⁊and play
This tresour hath fortune to vs geuyn
In myrthe and iolyte oure lyfe to lyuyn
And lightly as yt comyth so wil we yt dispende
Ey goddis precious dignyte who wende
This day that we shuld haue had so fayr a gᵃce
But myght this gold be caried from this place
Home to myn house or ellis to yourys
For wel I wot that al this gold is ourys
Than were we in hygh felicitee
But trewely by day yt may not bee
Men wold sey that we were theefis strong
And for oure owne tresour doo vs hong
This tresour most aryed by nyght
Als wysely and as slyly as yt myght
Wherfore I rede that cutte among vs alle
Be drawe ; and lete se where yt shal falle
He that the cutte happith with hert blythe
Shal renne to the toun and that as swythe
To bryng vs bred and wyne ful pryuely
And two of vs shal kepe ful subtily
The tresour wel ; and yif he wil not tary
Whan yt is nyght we wil the tresour cary
By one assent where that vs liketh best
That one of hem the cutte brought in his fest
And bad hem drawe and loke where yt wil falle
And yt fel on the yongest of them alle
And forth toward the toun he went anon
And als sone as that he was gon
That on of them spak thus vn to that othir
Thou wost wel that thou art my sworn brothir
Thi profyte wil I telle the anon
And also thou wost wel oure felawe is gon
And here is gold and that gret pleynte
That shuld be departid among vs thre
But neuer the lesse yif I can shape yt so
That yt were departid betwix vs two
Haue I not doon a frendis turn to the
That othir answerd I ne wot how þat myght be
He wot wel the good is with vs twey
What shal we doon what shal we sey
Shal yt be counsel seid the furst shrewe
And I shal telle the in wurdis fewe
How we shal doon and bring yt wel aboute
I graunt qd that othir out of doute
That by my trouthe I wil the not bewreye
Now quoth the furst we be but tweye
And yit two of vs shal strenger be than one
Looke whan that he is sette and þat anon
Arise as thou wold with hym play
And I shal renne hym thurgh the sidis tway
Whils that thou strugglist with hym as in game /
And with thi dagger looke þou do the same
And than shal al this gold departid be
My dere frend betwix me and the
Than may we bothe oure lustis fulfille
And play at the dyce right at oure own wille
And thus accordid been thise shrewis twey
To sle the thridde as yee haue herd me sey
The yongest which went vn to the toun
Ful ofte in his hert he musith vp and doun
On the beaute of thise floreyns newe and bright
O lord god qd he yif so were þat I myght
Haue al this tresour to my self allon
Ther nys no man that lyuys vndir the trone
Of god ; that shuld lyue meryer than I
And at the last the feend oure enemy
Put in his thought that he shuld poysou bye
With the which he myght sleen his felaws tweye
For whi the feend fond in hym such lyuyng
That he was leef to sorwe hem bryng
For this was vttirly his ful entent
To sleen hem bothe and neuer to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wold he tary
In to the toun vn to apotecary
And prayd hym that he to hym wold selle
Som poyson that he myght his rattys kylle
And eke ther was a polcat in his hawe
That as he seid his capoıı̄uns his capoıı̄uns had slawe
And seid he wold wrekyn hym yif he myght
On vermyn that distroyd hym day and nyght
The apotecary answerd and yee shal haue
A thing that as god my soule saue
In al this world ne is ther no creature
That etyn or drynkyn of this confecture
Not but the mountaunce of a corn of whete
And he shal anon his lyfe for lete
And sterue he shal and that in lasse while
Than thou wil gon a paas not a myle
The poysou is so strong and so violent
This cursid man has in his hand yt hent
This poysou in a box ; and sithen he ran
In to the next strete vn to a man
And borwid hym large botels thre
And in the two his poyson pouryd he
The thridde he kept clene for his drynk
For al the nyght he shoop hym for to swynk
In cariage of the gold out of that place
And whan this riotour with sory grace
Hadde fillid with wyne his grete botels thre
To his felawis ageyn repayrith he
What nedis yt to sermoun yt more
For right as thei had cast his deth before
Right so thei haue hym slayn and that anon
And whan that this was doon þan spak that on
Now lete vs drynk and sitte and make vs mery
And aftirward wil we his body bury
And aftirward happenyd hym par caas
To take the botel wherin the poyson was
And drank and gaf his felaw drynk also
For which anon thei dyed bothe two
But certis I suppose that auycen
Wrot neuer in no canon ne Innocen
Mo wondir sorwis of poysonyng
Thus haues this wrecchis two her endyng
Thus endid been thise homycidis two
And eke the fals enpoysoner also
Of cursid synne fallith cursidnesse
O traytours homycidis . O . wykkidnesse
O glotonye lecchery . O hasardye
Thou blasphemer of crist with vilenye
Of othis grete of vsage and of pryde
Allas mankynde how may it be
That to thi creatour which þat the wrought
And with his precious blood the bought
That art so fals and so vnkynd allas
Now good men godforgif you your trespas
And war yow fro the synne of auarice
My holy pardon may yow alle warice
So that yee offre noblys or sterlingis
Or ellis siluer sponys brochis or ryngis
Bowith your hed vndir this holy bulle
Comyth vp ye wyfes offrith your wulle
Your namys I entre here in my rolle anon
Vnto the blisse of heuyn shal yee gon
I yow assoyle by my high powere
Yee that wil offre as clene and as clere
As yee were born and lo sirs thus I preche
And ihu that is oure soule leche
So graunt yow this pardon to receyue
For that is best I wil not yow deceyue
But sirs a wurd forgat I in my tale
I haue reliquees and pardou in my male
As fayre as any man in england
Which were me gyffyn by the popis hand
Yif any of yow wil of deuocyoun
Offre and haue myne absolucyoun
Comyth forth a non and kneelith here a doun
And yee shal haue here gret pardoun
Or ellis takis pardou as yee wende
Al newe and fressh at euery townys ende
So that yee offre alwey newe and
Noblys and penyes which that been good ⁊and trewe
Yt is an honour to euerich that is here
That yee may haue a sufficient pardonere
To assoyle yow in cuntre as I ryde
For aduenturis the which may betide
Par aduenture ther may falle one or two
Doun of his hors and breke his necke in two
Lo such a sort yt is to yow alle
That I am in your felawship falle
That may assoyle yow bothe more and lesse
Whan that the soule shal fro the body passe
I rede that oure host shal begynne
For he is most volupt in synne
Come forth sir host and offre furst a non
And thou shal kisse the reliquees euerichon
Ye for a grote anon vnbukle thi purs
Nay nay quoth he than haue I cristis curs
Let be for yt shal not be so theech
Thou woldist make me kisse thyne olde brech
And swere yt were a Relique of a seynt
Though þat yt were with thi fundament depaynt
But by the croyce which þat seynt helen fond
I wold I had thi colyoıı̄uns in my hand
In stede of Reliques and of sanctuary
Lete kytte hem of and I wil help the hem to cary
Thei shal be shryned in an hoggis toord
This pardoner answerd not a wurd
So wroth he was that no thing wold he say
No lenger quoth oure host ne lyst me to play
With the ne with non angry man
But right anon the wurthi knyght began
Whan that he saw that al the poeple lowgh
Nomore of this for yt is right Inowgh
Sir pardoner be glad and mery of chere
And yee sir host that been to me so dere
I pray yow that yee kisse the pardonere
And pardoner I pray the drawe the neere
And as we did lat vs laugh and play
Anon thei kissid and ridyn forth her way

l.hi:
Explicit fabula perdonary ⁊and sub
sequenter incipt fabula naute sic .

div.l: A merchaunt whilom duellied at seynt denys
Þᵗat Riche was which men held ful wyse
A wyfe he hadde of excellent beaute
And compaynable and reuerent was she
Which is a thing that causith more dispence
Than wurth is al the chere and Reuerence
That men doon hem at festis and at dauncys
Suych salutacyouns and contenauncis
Passyn as dooth the shadow on a wal
But wo is hym that most pay for al
The sely husbond algate he must pay
He most vs clothe and vs array
Al for his owne wurship richely
In which array we daunce Iolily
And yif that he may not par aduenture
Or ellis no such dispensis endure
But thinkis yt is al wast and lost
Than most an othir pay for oure cost
And lene vs gold and that is ꝑper/parilous
This noble merchaunt held a noble hous
For which he hadde al day gret repayre
For his largesse and for his wyfe was fayre
What wondir ys yt ; but herkyn to my tale
Among alle his gestis gret and smale
Ther was a monk a fayr man and a bold
I trowe thrytti wynter he was old
That euer in one was drawyng to that place
This yong monk that was so fayre of face
Acqueynted was with the good man
Sithen that furst her knowlech be gan
That in hous as famulier was he
As is possible any man to be
And for als mekil as this good man
And eke this monk of the which I began
Were bothe two born in a village
The monk hym claymyth as for cosynage
And he agayn seith not onys nay
But als glad was therof as foule of day
For to his herte yt was gret pleasaunce
Thus thei ben knytte with etern alliaunce
And ich of hem gan othir for to assure
Of brothirhede whils that her lyfis endure
Fre was dan Iohn and manly of dispence
As in that hous and ful of diligence
To do largesse and gret costage
He not forgate to gyf the lest page
In al that hous but aftir her degree
He gaf the lord and sithen al the meynee
Whan that he come som maner of honest thing
For which thei were als glad of his comyng
As foule is fayn whan the sonne vp risith
No more of this as now for yt suffisith
But so befel this merchaunt on a day
Shoop hym to make redy his array
Toward the toun of brygges for to fare
To byen ther a porcyon of ware
For which he hath to parys sent a non
A messager for his cosyn dan Iohn
Oure dere cosyn ful of curtesy
With hym brought he a Iubbe of maluesy
And eke an othir ful of fyne vernage
And volatyle as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete and drynk and play
This merchaunt and this monk a day or tway
The thridde day this merchaunt vp rysith
And on his nedis hym sadly aviseth
And vp in to his countyng hous goth he
To rekken with hym self as wel may be
Of thilk yeer how that yt stood
And how that he dispendid had his good
And yif that he encresid were or non
His bookis and his baggis manyon
He leyth before hym on his countyng boorde
Ful riche was his tresour and his hord
For which ful fast he his countre dore shette
And eke he nold no man shuld hym lette
Of his accomptis in the mene while tyme
And thus he sat til yt was passid pryme
Dan Iohn was rysen in the morwe also
And in the gardyn walkid to and fro
And hath his thingis seid ful holily
This good wyfe cam walkyng pryuely
In to the gardyn ther he walkid soft
And hym salueth as she hath doon oft
A mayden child come in hir companye
Which as she lyst she may gouerne and guye
For yit vndir the yerde was the mayde
O dere cosyn myn dan Iohn she saide
What eylith yow thus erly for to aryse
Nece he saith yt ought ynoug suffice
Fyue hourys to slepe on a nyght
But yif yt were for an old pallid wight
As been thise weddid men that ligge and dare
As in a fourme sittys a wery hare
Þᵗat were al distraught wᵗith houndis gret ⁊and smale
But deere Nece whi been yee so pale
I trowe certis that your goodman
Hath yow labourid sithen þat nyght began
That yow were nede to rest hastily
And with that wurd he lough ful meryly
And of his owne thought he wex red
This fayre wyfe began to shake hir hed
And seid thus ye god wot al quoth she
Nay cosyn myn yt stondith not so with me
For by god that gaf me soule and lyfe
In al the realme of Fraunce is ther no wyfe
That lesse lust hath to that sory play
For I may syng allas and wel away
That I was born but to no wight qd she
Ne dar I telle how yt standis with me
Wherfore I thinke out of this land to wende
Or ellis of my self to make an ende
So ful am I of drede and eke of care
This monke began vppon hir to stare
And said allas my nece god for bede
That yee for any sorwe or any drede
For do your self but tellis me your greef
Par aduenture I may in your myscheef
Counsel and help and therfore tellys me
Al your anoye for yt shal be secree
For on my portos I make an othe
That Neuer in my lyfe for leef ne lothe
Ne shal I of no counsel yow bewreye
The same ageyn to yow I seye
But by god and by this portos I swere
Þough men wold me in to pecys tere
Ne shal I neuer for to go to helle
Bewrey wurd or thing that yee me telle
Not for no cosynage ne for non alliaunce
But verraly for loue and affiaunce
Thus thei been sworn and hervppon kist
And ilk of hem told othir what hem lyst
Cosyn qd she yif I had a space
As I haue non and namely in this place
Than wold I telle yow a legend of of my lyfe
That I haue suffrid sithen I was a wyfe
With my husbond ; alþough he be yoᵘur cosyn
Nay qd this monk by god and by seynt martyn
He is no more cosyn vn to me
Than is this leef that hengis on this tree
I clepe hym so be seynt denyse in Fraunce
To haue more cause of acquayntaunce
Of yow which I haue louyd especially
Aboue alle wommen sikirly
This swere I yow by my professioun
Tellith your greef lest he com a doun
And hastis yow and go your wey a non
My dere Loue qd she O dan Iohn
Ful leef me were this counsel to hide
But out yt must yt may no lenger abide
My husbond is to me the werst man
That euer was sithen that the world began
But sithen I am a wyfe yt sittys not to me
To telle no wight of oure pryuetee
Nouthir in bedde ne in non othir place
God sheld I shuld telle yt for his grace
A wyfe shal not sey of hir husbond
But al honour as I can vndirstond
Sauf vnto yow this mych telle I shal
So help me god he is not wurth at al
In no degree the valu of a flye
But yit me greuys most his nygardye
And wel ye wot that wommen naturally
Desyren vj thinges als wel as I
Thei wold that theyre husbondis shuld be
Hardy . wyse . riche . and fre .
And buxum to his wyfe and fressh in bedde
But by that lord that that for vs bledde
For his honour my self to array
On sunday next me must pay
A hundrith frankis for ellis I am lorn
Yet were I leuer I were vnborn
Than me were don a disclaundir or a vileny
And yif my husbond myght eke espye
I ne were but lost and therfore I yow preye
Lene me that somme or ellis I most deye
Dan Iohn I sey lene me thise hundrith frankys
Parde I wil not fayle yow my thankis
Yif that yee list do þat I pray
For at a certeyn day I wil yow pay
And do to yow what pleasaunce and seruyce
That I may doo right as yow list deuyse
And but I do god take of me vengeaunce
As foul as hadde gwenilyon of fraunce
This gentil Monk answered in this manere
Now truly myn own lady deere
I haue on yow so gret ruthe
That I yow swere and plight my truthe
That whan your husband is to flaundris fare
I wil delyuere yow out of al this care
And with that he caught hir by the flaunkys
And seid I wil bring yow an hundrith frankys
And hir enbrasid hard and kissid hir ofte
Go now your way qd he al stille and softe
And lat vs go to dyner as sone as ye may
For by my chalaundre yt is ner pⁱrime of þᵉ day
Go now and be as trewe as I shal be
Now god for bede ellid fro quoth she
And forth she goth als ioly as a pye
And bad the cokys that thei shuld hye
So that men myght dyne and that anon
Vp to hir husbond is this wyfe gon
And knokkis at his countyng dore baldly
Quy la . qd he ; petir yt am I .
Said she ; how long sir wil ye fast
How long wil yee rekne and cast
Your summez and your bokis and yoᵘur thing
The deuyl haue part of al such reknyng
Yee haue ynough parde of goddis sonde
Come doun to day and lat yoᵘur baggis stonde
Be yee not ashamyd that dan Iohn
Shal fast al this day so long gon
What lat vs here messe and go we dyne
Whi qd this man litil can thou deuyne
The curious besynesse that we haue
For of chapmen so god me saue
And by that lord þat clepid is seynt yue
Skarsly among twenty two . shal thryue
Contynuelly lastyng vnto oure age
We may wel make cheere and good visage
And dryue forth the world as yt may be
And kepe oure estate in pryuete
Til that we be ded or ellis that we play
A pilgrimage or gon out of the way
And therfor haue I gret necessite
Vppon this quaynt world to aduyse me
For euermore we most stand and drede
Of happe and fortune in oure chapman hede
To flaundris I wil go to morwe at day
And come ageyn as sone as euer I may
For which my deer wyfe I the beseke
As be to euery buxum and meke
And for to kepe oure good be curious
And honestly gouerne wel oure hous
Thou hast ynough in euery maner wyse
That to a thrifty husbond may suffice
The lakkith non array ne no vitayle
Of siluer in thi purs thou may not fayle
And with that wurd his count̉er/redore he shette
And doun he goth no lenger wold he lette
But hastily a messe was ther said
And spedily the tablis were layd
And to the dyner fast thei hem spedde
And richely the chapman the monk fedde
And aftir dyner dan Iohn sobirly
This chapman took on side pryuely
And said thus cosyn yt standith so
That wel I se to bruggis wil yee go
God and seynt augustyne yow spede ⁊and guyde
I pray yow cosyn that yee wysely ryde
Gouernyth yow also of your dyete
Al temperelly and Namely in this hete
Betwix vs two nedith no straunge fare
Fare wel cosyn god sheeld yow fro care
Yif any thing ther be by day or nyght
Yif yt ligge in my power and my myght
That yee wil comaunde me in any wyse
Yt shal be doon right as yee wil deuyse
One thing or that yee gon yif yt may be
I wold pray yow to lene me
An hundrith frankis for a wyke or tweye
For certeyns bestis that me must bye
To store with a place of ourys
God help me so I wold yt were youris
I shal not fayle seurly of my day
Not for a hundrith frankis a myle way
But lete this thing be secree I yow pray
For thise bestis this nyght yit most I pay
And fare now wel myn owne cosyn deere
Graund mercy of your cost and of your chere
The noble merchaunt gentilly a non
Answerd and seid O cosyn dan Iohn
Now sikirly this is a smal request
My gold is youris whan that yow lest
Not only my gold but my chaffare
Take what yee lust god sheeld ye spare
But one thing as yee know yt wel ynough
Of chapmen that þer mony is ther plough
We may make whils that we haue a name
But goldles to be ne is no game
Pay yt ageyn whan yt lyes in your ease
Aftir my myght ful fayn I wold yow please
Thise . C . fraunkis he fecchid forth anon
And pryuely he took hem to dan Iohn
No wight in al this world wist of this lone
Sauf this merchaund and dan Iohn allone
Thei drynke and speke and rome a while ⁊and play
Til that dan Iohn ridith til his abbay
The morwe cam and forth this mchant rydith
To flaundrisward his apprentice wel hym guydith
Til he come to bruggis merily
Now gos this merchaunt fast and besily
About his nede and byeth and creaunsith
He nouthir pleyeth at the dyce ne daunsith
But as merchaunt shortly for to telle
He ladde his lyfe and there I lete hym dwelle
The sonday next dan Iohn þat þe mchaunt is gon
To seynt denyse is come dan Iohn
With crowne and al fressh and newe shaue
In al the hous ne is ther man ne knave
Ne no wight ellis but that he was fayn
That my lord dan Iohn was comyn agayn
And shortly to here poynt thei gon
To seynt denyse is comyn dan Iohn this fayre wyfe accordis with dan Iohn
And for thise hundrith fraunkis he shuld a nyght
Haue her in his armys bolt vpright
And this accord ꝑper/parfourmyd was in dede
In myrth al nyght a besy lyfe thei lede
Til yt was day dan Iohn went his way
And bad the meyne far wel and haue good day
For non of hem ne no wight in the toun
Hath of dan Iohn right no suspeccyoun
But forth he ridis hom to his abbay
Or where hym lust no more of hym I say
This merchaunt whan that endid was the fayre
To seynt denyse he gan to repayre
And with his wyfe he makis feste and chere
And tellis hir that chaffare is so dere
That nedis most he make cheuysaunce
Of som of his frendis or his alliaunce
To pay xx Mˢ stutys anon
For which this merchaunt is to parys gon
To borwe of certeyn frendis that he hadde
A certeyn fraunkis and som with hym he ladde
And whan he was comyn vnto that toun
For cheerte and gret affeccyoun
Vnto dan Iohn he furst gos hym to play
Not for to borwe of hym no monay
But for to wyt and see of his welfare
And for to tellyn hym of his chaffare
As frendis doon whan thei be mette in fere
Dan Iohn hym makis fest and mery cheere
And hym he told ageyn ful specially
How he hadde bought wel and graciously
Thankid be god his merchaundyse
Sauf that he most in al maner wyse
Make a cheuysaunce as for the best
And than he shuld lyuyn in Ioye and rest
Dan Iohn answerd certis I am fayn
That yee in hele are comyn agayn
And that I were riche so haue I blisse
Of xx Mˢ stutis shuld yee not mysse
For yee so kyndly this othir day
Lent me gold ; and as I can or may
I thanke yow by god and by seynt Iame
But neuer the lesse I took vnto oure dame
Your wyfe at home the same money ageyn
Vppon your benke she wot yt wel certeyn
By certeyn tokenys that I can hir telle
Now by your leue I may no lenger duelle
Oure abbot wil out of this toun anon
And in his compeny most I gon
Grete wel oure dame my nece swete
And fare wel dere cosyn til we mete
This merchaunt was bothe redy and wyse
Creaunsid he has and payed eke in paryse
To certeyn lumbardys and pays redy in þ̉er/re hond
The somme of gold and tooke of hem the bond
And hom he goth as mery as a popyn iay
For wel he knew he stood in such aray
The nedis must he wynne in such a viage
A hundrith frankis ouer al his costage
His wyfe ful redy mette hym at the gate
As she was wont of vsage late
And al that nyght in myrthe thei besette
For he was riche and clerly out of dette
Whan yt was day this merchant gan enbrace
His wyfe al newe and kissid hir in the face
And vp he goth and makis yt ful tough
Nomore quoth she by god yee haue ynough
And wommanly with hym she played
Til at the last this merchaunt said
By god I am a lytil wroth
With yow my wyfe al though yt be me loth
And wot ye whi by god as þat I gesse
That yee haue made a litil strangenesse
Betwix me and my cosyn dan Iohn
Yee shuld haue warnyd me er I had gon
That he had to yow a hundrith frankis payd
By redy tokene and held hym euyl a payd
For that I to hym spake of cheuyssaunce
Me semyd so by his contynaunce
But Neuer the lesse by god heuyn kyng
I thought not to aske hym no thyng
I pray the wyfe do no more so
Telle me alway or that I fro the go
Yif any dettour haue in myn absence
I payd the lest thurgh my necligence
I may aske a thing that he has paid
This wyfe was nouthir afferd ne affrayd
But holly she said and that a non
Mary I diffye the fals monk dan Iohn
I kepe not of tokenys neuer a del
He took me certeyn gold þat wot I wel
What euyl thedam on his monkis snowte
For god yt wot withoutyn doute
I wend he had geuyn yt me by cause of yow
To do therwith myn honour and my prow
For cosynage and eke for bele chere
That he hath had ful oftyn tymes here
But sithen yt stondith in this desioynt
I wil answer yow shortly to the poynt
Yee haue no slakker dettour þan am I
For I wil pay yow wel and redily
Fro day to day and yif so be that I fayle
I am your owne score vppon my tayle
And I shal pay yt as sone as euer I may
For by my trouthe I haue yt on myn aray
And not in wast bestowid euery deel
And for I haue bestowid yt so wel
To your honour for goddis sake I say
As be not wroth but lete vs laugh and play
Yee shal my ioly body haue to wedde
By god I nyl not payd yt yow but in bedde
Forgif yt me myn owne spouse deere
Turn hiderward and make bettyr cheere
This merchaunt saw ther is no bettir remedy
And for to chide yt was but foly
Sithen that this thing amendid may not be
Wyfe he said I forgif yt the
But by thi lyfe be nomore so large
Kepe bettyr my good this gyf I the in charge
Thus endith now my tale and god vs sende
Talkyng ynowgh to oure lyfys ende

l.hi: ⁊and subsequenter incipit prohemium fabulePriorisse hoc modo sequente

div.l: Uel seid by corpus dus qd oure host
Long mot thou seyle by the coost
Thou gentyl maystir gentyl Marynere
God gyue the monk a thousand quadiere
A . a . felowys bewar of such a Iape
The monk put in the mannys hood an ape
And in the wyfis eke by seynt augustyn
Drawith no monkis more to youre In
But now passe ouer and lat vs seche about
Who shal telle now furst of al this rout
An othir tale and with þat wurde he said
As curtesly as yt had been a mayde
My lady prioresse by your leue
So that I . wist I shuld not yow greue
I wold deme that yee telle shuld
A tale next ; yif so were that yee wold
Now wil yee vouchesauf my lady deere
Gladly qd she and seyd as yee shal here
O lord of lordis þi name how mervailous /
Is in this wide world I spred qd she
Nought only thi louyng so precyous
Parfourmyd is by men of dignyte
By the mouthe of childern thi bounte
Parfourmyd is for on the breest sowkyng
Som tyme shew thei thi hereyng
¶ Wherfore in laude as I . best can or may
Of the and of the white lily floure
Whiche that the bare and is a mayde alway
To telle an history I wil do my labour
Not that I may encresyn hir honour
For she hir self is honour and the roote
Of bounte next hir sone and soulys boote
¶ O moder mayde O mayde moder fre
O bush vnbrent brennyng in moyses sight
That rauesshid doun from the dette
Thurgh þyn humblenesse þe gost þat in þe alight
Of whos vertu whan he thi hert light
Conceyuyd was the fadres sapience
Help me to telle yt in thi Reuerence
¶ Lady thi bounte thi magnyficence
Thi vertu and thi gret humylite
Ther may no tunge expresse in no science
For sum tyme lady er men prey to the
Thou gost byforn of thi benyngnyte
And getest vs the light of thi prayere
To guyden vs vnto thi sone so dere
¶ My kıı̄unnyng is to wayke . O . blisseful queene
For to declare thi gret wurthynesse
That ne may the weight sustene
But as a child of xij moneth old or lesse
That can vnnethe any wurd expresse
Right so fare I and therfore I yow preye
Guydeth my song that I shal of yow seye
¶ Ther was is asye in a gret cytee
Among cristen folk a Iewerye
Sustenyd by a lord of that cuntre
For foul vsure and lucre of vilanye
Hateful to criste and to his compaignye
And thurgh the strete men myght ride ⁊and wende
For yt was fre and opyn at outhir ende
¶ A lytel scole of cristen folk ther stood
Doun at the forther ende in which ther were
Childern an hepe y comyn of cristyn blood
That lernyd in that scole yeer by yeere
Such maner doctryne as was vsid there
This is to seyn to synge and to rede
As smale childern doon in here childhede
¶ Among thise childern was a viduys sone
A litil clergyon of seuen yeer of age
That day by day to scole was his wone
And eke also where he saw the ymage
Of cristis modir ; he had in vsage
As hym was taught to knele a doun ⁊and seye
His aue maria as he goth by the weye
¶ Thus hath this vidue hir lytil sone ytaught
Oure blisseful lady cristis modir deere
To wurship ay ; and he forgate yt nought
For theyvand child wil alwey sone leere
But ay whan I remembre on this matere
Seynt Nicholas standith euer in my presence
For he so yong to cryste did Reuerence
¶ This litil child his lytil book lernyng
As he sat in the scole at his prymere
He alma redemptoris herd syng
As childern lernyd her antiphonere
And as he durst he drough hym neer ⁊and nere
And herknyd ay the wurdis and þe note
Til he the furst verse can al by rote
¶ Not wist he what this latyn was to sey
For he so yong and tendre was of age
But on a day his felaw gan he pray
To expoun hym this song in his language
Or telle hym whi this song was in vsage
This prayd he hym to constru and declare
Ful ofte tyme vppon his knees bare
¶ His felawe which þat elder was þan he
Answerd hym thus this song I haue herd say /
Was made for oure blisseful lady fre
Hir to salue and eke hir for to pray
To been oure help and socour whan we dey
I can no more expoun in this matere
I lerne song I can but smal gramere
¶ And is this song made in the Reuerence
Of cristis modir ; seid this Innocent
Now certis I wil do my diligence
To kunne yt al or cristemesse be went
Þough I for my prymer shal be shent
And shal be betyn thryes in an hour
I wil yt kōmne oure lady to honour
¶ His felawe taught hym homward pryuely
From day to day til he couth yt by rote
And than he song yt wel and boldly
Froward toward accordyng with the note
Twyes on the day yt passid thurgh his throte
To scoleward and homward whan he went
On cristis modir sette was his entent
¶ As I haue seid ; thurghout the Iewrye
This litel child as he cam to and fro
Ful merily wold he synge and crye
O alma redemptoris euermo
The swetnesse his herte percyd so
Of cristis modir that to hir to preye
He can not stynte of syngyng by the weye
¶ Oure furste fo the serpent sathanas
That hath in Iewis hert his waspis nest
Vpswal and seid . O hebrayk poeple allas
Is this to yow a thing þat is honest
That such a boye shal walkyn as hym lest
In your despite and syng of such sentence
Which is ageyn your lawis Reuerence
¶ From thens forth the iewis hem conspirid
This Innocent out of this world to chace
An homicide therto haue thei hiryd
That in an aley lay at a preuy place
And as the child gan forby for to pace
Thus cursid Iewe hym hent and held hym fast
And kytte his throte ; and in a pytte hym cast
¶ I sey that in a wardrop thei hym threwe
Where as thise iewis purgyn her entrail
O cursid folk O . herodes al newe
What may your euyl entent yow avail
Mordre wil out certeyn yt wil not fayl
And namely ther as the honoᵘur of god shal sprede
The blood out crieth on your cursid dede
¶ O martyr sowdid to virginite
Now may thou syng euer in one
The white lambe celestial qd she
Of which the grete euᵃngelist seynt Iohn
In pathmos wrot which seith þᵗat þei þat gon
Before this lambe and syng a song al newe
That neuer flesshly wommen þei knewe
¶ This pouer widue awaitith al the nyght
Aftir hir litil child but he cam nought
For which as sone as yt was day light
With face pale of drede and besy thought
She hath at scole and ellis where hym sought
Til fynally she gan so fer espye
That he last seyn was in the Iewrye
¶ With modirs pytee in hir brest enclosid
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To euery place where as she hath supposid
By lyklyhod hir litil child to fynde
And euer on cristis modir meke and kynde
She cryed and at the last thus she wrought
Among the cursid iewis she hym sought
¶ She freynyth and she preyth pitously
To euery Iewe that dwellid in thilk place
To telle hir yif hir child went ought forby
Thei seide nay ; but Ihu of his grace
Gaf in hir thought within a litil space
That in that place aftir hir sone she cryde
Where he was cast in a pytte biside
¶ O grete god that parfourmest thi laude
By mouthe of Innocentys lo thi myght
This gemme of chastite this emeraude
And eke in martirdom the rubye bright
Ther he with throte I coruyn lay vpright
He alma redemptoris gan to synge
So lowde that al the place gan to rynge
¶ The cristyn folk that thurgh the strete went
In comyn for to wondre on this thing
And hastily thei for the prouost sent
And he cam anon without tareyng
And heryeth criste that is of heuyn kyng
And eke his modir honour of mankynde
And aftir that . the iewis lete he bynde
¶ This child with pitous lamentacyoun
Vp takyn was singyng his song alway
And with honour of gret processioun
Thei caryen hym vnto the next abbey
His moder swounyng by his bere lay
Vnnethe myght the poeple that was there
This newe Rachel bryng fro his bere
¶ With turment and with shameful deth ichon
This ꝓprouost doth the Iewis for to sterue
That of this mordre wist and that anon
He nold no such cursidnesse obserue
Euyl shal he haue that euyl wil deserue
Therfore with wild hors he did hem drawe
And aftir that he hyng hem by the lawe
¶ Vppon this bere ay liggeth this Innocent
Before the cheef auter whils the masse last
And aftir that . the abbot with his couent
Haue sped hem for to buryen hym ful fast
And whan thei holy water on hym cast
Yit spak this child whan spreynd was holy water
And song O alma redemptoris mater
¶ This abbot which that was an holy man
As monkis been or ellis ought to be
This yong child to coniuryn he began
And seide o . dere child haylse the
In the vertu of the trinite
Telle me what is thi cause for to singe
Sithen that thi throte is kytte to my semynge
¶ My throte is kytte vnto my nekke bon
Seide this child ; and as by weye of kynde
I shuld haue dyed ye long tyme agon
But Ihu criste as yee in bookis fynde
Wil that his glory last and be in mynde
And for the wurship of his moder dere
Yit may I syng O alma lowde and clere
¶ This welle of mercy cristis modir swete
I louyd alway as aftir my konnyng
And whan that I my lyfe shuld forlete
To me she cam and bad me for to syng
This anteme verrely in my dyeng
As yee haue herd and whan that I had songe
Me thought she leid agreyn vppon my tunge
¶ Wherfore I syng ; and syng mot certeyn
In honour of that blisseful mayde fre
Til fro my tunge be takyn the greyn
And aftir that thus seide she to me
My child now wil I the fecche þe
Whan that the greyne is fro thi tong I take
Be not agast I wil not the forsake
¶ This holy monk this abbot hym mene I .
His tunge out caught and took away þe greyn
And he gaf vp the gost ful softly
And whan this abbot had this wondre seyn
His salt terys tryklid doun as reyn
And gruf he fel al flat vppon the grounde
And stille he lay as he had ley ybounde
¶ The couent eke lay on the pauyment
Wepyng and hereyng cristis modir dere
And aftir that thei resyn and forth þei went
And took awey this matyre from his bere
And in a tombe of marble stonys clere
Enclosid thei his litil body swete
There he is now god leue vs for to mete
¶ O yong hugh of lincoln slayn also
With cursid Iewys as yt is notable
For yt is but a litil while a go
Preye eke for vs we synful folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so mercyable
On vs his grete mercy multiplye
For Reuerence of his modir marye

l.hi:
⁊and subsequenter sequntur verba
hospitis ad Chauncers

div.l: Uhan seid was this myracle eủer/rey man
As sobre was that wondre yt was to see
Til that oure host brekyn out began
And than at erst he lokid vppon me
And said thus what man art thou qd he
That lokyst as thou wolde fynde an hare
For euer vppon the grounde I se the stare
¶ Approche neer and loke vp myrily
Now ware yow sirs and lat this man haue space
He in the waste is shapyn als wel as I
This were a popet in armys to enbrace
For any womman smal and fayre of face
He semyth eluyssh by his contynaunce
For vnto no wight dooth he daliaunce
¶ Sey now sumwhat sithen othir folk haue seid
Telle vs a tale of myrthe and that anon
Host qd I ne be not euyl a paid
For othir tale certis can I non
But of a Ryme I lernyd long agon
Ye that is good qd he now shal we here
Sum deynteth thing me thynkis by his chere

l.hi: Hic narrat fabula sua Chauncersde quodam milite Thopas

div.l: Lystnyth lordynges in good entent
And I wil telle verrament
Of myrthe and of solace
Al of a knyght was fayre and gent
In batayle and in turnament
His name was sir Thopace
¶ I born he was in fer cuntre
In flaundris al by yonde the see
At poperyng in the place
His fadir was a man ful fre
And lord he was of that cuntre
As yt was goddis grace
¶ Sir thopas wex a doughty swayn
Whyte was his face as the payndemayn
His lippes red as rose
His rudde is lyke skarlet in grayn
As I yow telle in good certeyn
He hadde a semely nose
Nomore of this for goddis dignyte
Quoth oure host for thou makist me
So wery of thi verray lewdenesse
That as wistly god my soule blisse
My erys ake of thi drasshi speche
Now swich a ryme the deuyl I beteche
This may wel be ryme doggerel qd he
Whiso quoth I whi wil thou lette me
More of my tale than an othir man
Sithen that is the best ryme that I can
By god qd he for pleynly at a wurd
Thi drasshi rymyng is not wurth a turd
Thou doost not ellis but dispendist tyme
Sir at one wurd thou shalt no lenger ryme
Lat se yif thou canst ought telle in geste
Or telle in prose sum what at the leste
In which ther be sum myrthe or sum doctryne
Gladly qd I by goddis swete pyne
I wil yow telle a litil thing in prose
That ought to like yow as I suppose
Or ellis certis yee been to daungerous
Yt is a moral tale vertuous
Al þough yt be told sum tyme in sundry wyse
Of sundry folk as I shal yow deuyse
As thus yee wot that the euᵃngelist
That tellith vs the peyne of Ihu crist
Ne seith al thing as his felawe dooth
But neuer the lesse her sentence is al soth
And alle accordyn in her sentence
Al though ther be in her tellyng difference
For sum of hem seyn more and sum seyn lesse
Whan thei his pitous passyon expresse
I mene of Mark matheu luke and Iohn
But doutles here sentence is al one
Therfore lordyngis alle I yow beseche
Yif that yee thinke I vary as in my speche
As thus þough þat I telle sumwhat More
Of prouerbes than yee haue herd before
Comprehendid in this litel tretyce here
To enforce with the effecte of my matere
And though I not the same wurdes seye
As yee haue herd yit to yow alle I preye
Blameth me not ; for as in my sentence
Yee shal nowher fynde difference
Fro the sentence of this tretyce lyte
Aftir the whiche this mery tale I wryte
And therfore herkyneth what I shal sey
And lat me telle al my tale I prey
Whan endid was my tale of myllebe
And of prudence and hir benignynyte
Oure ost seid as I am faythful man
And by the pcious corpus Madrian
Had I leuer than a barell of ale
That good leeff my wyfe had herd this tale
For she nys nothing of such pacience
As was this mellibeez wyfe prudence
By cokkis bonys whan I bete my knavys
She brynges me gret clubbys and stafys
And cryes sle the doggis euerichon
And breke of hem both bak and bon
And yif any neigbour of myne
Wil not in chirche to my wyfe inclyne
Or be so hardy to hir to trespace
Whan she comys hom she raunpis in my face
And cryes fals coward wreke thi wyfe
By cokkis bonys I wil haue thi knyfe
And thou shalt haue my distaf and go spyn
Fro day to nyght thus she wil begyn
Allas she seith that euer I was shape
To wedde a mylkesoppe a coward an ape
That wil be ouyr led with euery wight
Thou darst not stondyn be thi wyfes right
This is my lyfe but yif that I wil fight
And out at the dore a non I most me dight
Or ellis I am bot lost but yif that I
Be lyke a wood leon ful hardy
I wot wel she wil doon me sle som day
Of som neigbour and than renne a way
For I am perilous with knyfe in honde
Al þough yt be I dar not hir withstonde
For she is bigge in armys by my feith
That shal he fynde that hir mysdooth or seith
But lat vs passe away fro this matere
My lord the monk quoth he of so mery a chere
Yee shal telle a tale truly
Lo Rouchestre standeth here fast by
Ride forth breke not your owne game
But be my trouth I knowe not yoᵘur name
Wheither shal I calle yow my lord dan Iohn
Or dan Thomas or dan albon
Of what hous be yee by your fadir kyn
I avowe to god thou hauyst a ful fayr skyn
Yt is a gentil pasture ther thou gost
Thou art not lyke a penaunt or a gost
Vppon my faith thou art an officere
Som wurthi sacristan or som celeleere
For by fadir soule as to my doom
Thou art a mayster whan thou art at hom
No pouer cloystrer ne no nouyce
But a gouernoᵘur witty and wyse
And therwithal of brawne and bonys
A wel faryng ꝑper/parsone for the nonys
I pray god gyf hym confusion
That furst the brought to Religioun
For thou woldist haue been a dredful man aright
Haddist thou as gret loue as thou hast myght
To parfourme al thi lust in engendrure
Thou haddist getyn many a creature
Allas whi werys thou so wyde a cope
God gyf me sorwe and I were a pope
Not only thou but euery myghti man
Þough he were shove brode vppon his pan
Shuld haue a wyfe for al this world is lorn
Religioun has takyn vp al the corn
Of tredyng ; and we burel men be but shrympis
Of feble trees ther comys feble ympis
This makis that oure heyres be so slender
And feble that thei may not wel engendre
This makis that oure wyfes wil assay
Religious folk for thei may bettir pay
Be not wroth my lord though I play
For ofte in game the sooth I haue herd say
This wurthi monk took al in pacience
And said I wil doon al my diligence
As fer forth as sowneth in to honeste
o telle yow a tale two or three
And yif list to herkyn hiderward
I . wil sey the lyfe of seynt Edward
Or ellis furst of tregedyes I wil you telle
Of which I haue an hundreth in my celle
Tregedy is for to seyn a certayn history
As old bokes makis vs memory
Of hem that stood in gret ꝓprosꝑper/paryte
And are fallyn out of their degree
In to myseri and endyn wrecchidly
And thei been versifyed comynly
Of sex feet which men clepyn exametton
In prose been eke endited Manyon
And in metre eke and in sundry wyse
Lo this declaryng wil ynough suffice
Now herkenys yif yow likes to here
But furst I yow beseche in this matere
Þough I be ordre telle not here thise thynges
Be yt of popis emprours or kynges
Aftir here age as men wrytyn fynde
But telle hem som before and sum behynde
As yt comys now in my Remembraunce
Haue me excusid of myn ignoraunce

Non plus de ista fabula quia est valde
dolorosa sed consequenter incipiunt ver-
ba militis ad monachum sic
HO qd the knyght goode no more of þis .
Þat yee haue seid is right ynough ywis .
And mekil more for litel heuynesse
Ys right ynough to mykel folk I gesse
Your talys dooth vs nouthir disport ne gme
Wherfore ʆser/sir monk or dan Iohn by yoᵘur name
I pray yow hertily telle vs sum what ellis
For sekirly ne were the gynglyng of yoᵘur belys
That on your brydel hengyn on euery side
By heuyn kyng that for vs alle dyde

As whan Nero brent the Cytee

For that their husbondis lost alle their lyfes
Without gilt this Nero has hem slayn
Now wil I turne to my tale agayn
This sely widu and her doughtris two
Herd their hennys cry and make wo
And out at the dore stert thei anon
And saw the fox toward the groue gon
And bare vppon his bakke the cokke away
And cryed out and harrow and wel away
A A war the fox and aftir hym thei ran
And eke with staffis many an othir man
Ran Colle oure dogge talbot and garlond
And malkyn with a distaffe in hir hand
Ran cow and calf and the very hoggis
So ferd were thei for berkyng of þe doggis
And showtyng of the men and woumen eke
Thei Ran so hem thought here hert did breke
Thei yellid as feendis dou in helle
The doggis cryed as men wold hem quelle
The gees for ferd flowe ouer the trees
Out of the hyfe come the swarme of bees
So hidous was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iakke strawe and his meynee
Ne made neuer showtis half so shille
Whan that thei wold any flemmyng kille
As thilk day was made vppon the fox
Of brasse thei broughtyn bemys and of box
Of horn and bon in which thei blew ⁊and poupid
And therwithal þei strakid and þei houpid
Yt semed as that heuyn shuld falle
Now good men I pray yow herknyth alle
Lo how fortune turnyth subitanly
The hope and the pryde of enuy
This cokke that lay vppon the foxis bakke
In al his drede vn to the fox he spakke
And seid sir yif I were as yee
Yit shuld I sey als wystly god help me
Turnyth ageyn ye proud cherlis alle
A verrey pestilence mot on yow befalle
Now am I comyn to the wode side
Malgree your hed the cokke shal here abyde
The fox answerd in faith yt shal be don
I wil yt sey in feith and þat anou
And spak that wurd and subitanly
This cokke brak fro his mouth delyuerly
And whan the fox saw that he was gon
On high vppon a tree anon
Allas quoth he Chauntler allas
I haue doon to yow a gret trespas
In as mych as I made yow a ferd
Whan I yow hent and brought vnto this yerd
But sir I did yt in no wykkid entent
Come doun and I shal telle yow what I ment
I shal sey the sooth to yow god help me so
Nay than quoth he I shrewe vs bothe two
And furst I shrewe my self bothe blood ⁊and bonys
Yif þou begyle any ofter þan onys
Thou shalt no more with flaterye
Make me syng and wynke with myn eye
For he that wynkyth whan he shuld see
Almyghty god lat hym neuer the
Nay mary quoth the fox god gyf hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaunce
Þat ianglith whan he shuld hold his pees
Lo such it is to be Recheles
And necligent and trust in flaterye
But yee that holdyn this tale a folye
As of a fox and of a cokke and of a henne
Take the moralte good men
For seynt poule seith al that wrytyn is
To oure doctryne yt is wryten ywis
Takith the frute and lat the chaf be stille
Now good god yif yt be thi wille
As seith my lord make vs alle good men
And bryng vs to thyn heuyn blisse amen
